book.name: Jeremiah
book.info: The late seventh and early sixth centuries B.C.

This book covers a period of at least forty-two years, from 628 B.C., the thirteenth year of Josiah's reign ([link]1:2[/link]), until some time after 586 B.C., after Gedaliah the governor of Judah was murdered ([link]41:2[/link]) and Jeremiah was carried away to Egypt ([link]43:6-8[/link]).
book.subject: Christ Being Made the Righteousness of Jehovah to God's Elect as Their Center and Circumference, in God's Dealings with Israel and the Nations

verse.text: The words of [note]1[/note]Jeremiah the son of Hilkiah, of the priests who were in Anathoth in the land of Benjamin,
verse.note: Meaning perhaps [i]Jah exalts,[/i] or [i]Jah tears down; Jah[/i] being a shortened form of [i]Jehovah.[/i]

verse.text: To whom the word of Jehovah came in the days of [xref]a[/xref]Josiah the son of Amon the king of Judah, in the thirteenth year of his reign.

It came also in the days of [xref]a[/xref]Jehoiakim the son of Josiah the king of Judah until the end of the eleventh year of [xref]b[/xref]Zedekiah the son of Josiah the king of Judah, until the [xref]c[/xref]captivity of Jerusalem in the fifth month.
Now the word of Jehovah came to me, saying:

Before I [xref]a[/xref]formed you in the womb, I [xref]b[/xref]knew you; / And before you came forth from the womb, I [xref]c[/xref]sanctified you. / I have [note]1[/note]appointed you as a prophet to the nations.
verse.note: Lit., given. Jeremiah was born a priest ([link]v. 1[/link]), but he was called by God to be a prophet not only to the nation of Israel but also to all the nations ([link]vv. 5-8[/link]). Hence, he was a priest-prophet.[br][br]The content of Jeremiah's prophecy is God's carrying out of His economy through His chastisement of Israel, His elect, in love with His tender care, compassion, and sympathy, and His judgment on the nations in righteousness to match His love, that Israel may manifest Christ, who is their divine righteousness ([link]23:6[/link]; [link]33:16[/link]) as their centrality and universality, by their being made a new creation with the inner law of the divine life and the capacity of this life to know God ([link]31:33-34[/link]).

verse.text: Then I said, Alas, Lord Jehovah! / Indeed, I do not know how to [xref]a[/xref]speak, / For I am a youth.
But Jehovah said to me, / Do not say, I am a youth; / For everywhere I send you, you shall go; / And everything I command you, you shall speak.
Do [xref]a[/xref]not be afraid of their faces, / For I am [xref]b[/xref]with you to deliver you, declares Jehovah.
Then Jehovah stretched out His hand and touched my [xref]a[/xref]mouth; and Jehovah said to me,[br/]Now I have [xref]b[/xref]put My words in your mouth.
See, I have appointed you this day / Over the nations and over the kingdoms / To [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]pluck up and to break down, / To destroy and to tear down, / To build up and to plant.
verse.note: The plucking up, the breaking down, and the destroying are Jehovah's tearing down, whereas the building up and the planting are Jehovah's exalting. This corresponds to the two meanings of Jeremiah's name (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup][/link]). Jehovah's building up and His planting both involve His word. God's word is a building up of Christ and a planting of Christ for the exalting of Christ ([link]Acts 20:32[/link]; [link]Mark 4:14[/link]).

verse.text: Then the word of Jehovah came to me, saying, What do you see, Jeremiah? And I said, I see a [note]1[/note]rod of an [xref]a[/xref]almond tree.
verse.note: Related to the word [i]watch,[/i] found in [link]v. 12[/link]. Here the rod of an almond tree signifies that God was watching over His word in order to fulfill it, i.e., to execute His word to punish Israel (cf. [link]Deut. 28:15-68[/link]).

verse.text: And Jehovah said to me, You have seen well, for I am watching over My word to perform it.
Then the word of Jehovah came to me a second time, saying, What do you see? And I said, I see a [note]1[/note]boiling [xref]a[/xref]pot, and it is facing away from the north.
verse.note: The boiling pot facing away from the north signifies that out of the north (referring especially to Babylon) calamities (evil — [link]v. 14[/link]) would be let loose ([link]4:6b[/link]) upon all the inhabitants of Israel.

verse.text: And Jehovah said to me, Out of the [xref]a[/xref]north evil will be let loose upon all the inhabitants of the land.

For I am now calling all the families from the kingdoms of the north, declares Jehovah, and they will come and set each one his throne at the entrance of the gates of Jerusalem and against all its walls all around and against all the cities of Judah.

And I will utter My judgment on them concerning all their wickedness by which they have forsaken Me and have burned incense to other gods and have worshipped the [xref]a[/xref]works of their own hands.
You therefore [xref]a[/xref]gird up your loins, and rise up and speak to them everything that I command you. Do not be dismayed before them, lest I dismay you in their presence.

[xref]a[/xref]And I am now making you today into a [note]1[/note]fortified city and into an iron pillar and into bronze walls against the whole land, against the kings of Judah, against its princes, against its priests, and against the people of the land.
verse.note: On earth there is always a battle raging between God and those who oppose Him and fight against Him. God fights not by Himself directly but through His servants who have been sent by Him. This was the situation in Jeremiah's time. God sent His army — a young man named Jeremiah — to fight against those who opposed Him. Jeremiah was equipped by God to such an extent that he became a fortified city and an iron pillar and brass walls. Because God was with him to deliver him, the opposers would not prevail over him ([link]v. 19[/link]).

verse.text: And they will fight against you, but they will not prevail against you; for I am with you, declares Jehovah, to deliver you.
And the word of Jehovah came to me, saying,

Go and cry in the ears of Jerusalem, saying, Thus says Jehovah: / I remember concerning you the kindness of your [xref]a[/xref]youth, / The [xref]b[/xref]love of your [note]1[/note]bridal days, / When you [xref]c[/xref]followed after Me in the wilderness, / In a land that was not sown.
verse.note: Or, betrothals. In this book Jehovah God considers Himself a Husband to His beloved elect, Israel, and Israel a wife to Him ([link]2:2[/link], [link]22[/link]; [link]3:1[/link], [link]14[/link]; [link]31:32[/link]). [link]Jeremiah 2:1-3:5[/link] can thus be regarded as a conversation between a husband and his wife. See note [link]6[sup]2[/sup] in Exo. 20[/link].

verse.text: Israel was [xref]a[/xref]holiness to Jehovah, / The [xref]b[/xref]firstfruits of His [note]1[/note]increase; / All who ate of it were guilty; / Evil came upon them, / Declares Jehovah.
verse.note: Or, harvest; produce from the earth. God gained some increase from the earth as produce, and Israel was the firstfruits of this produce. God treasured Israel as holiness to Him, as the firstfruits of His increase from His field.

verse.text: Hear the word of Jehovah, O house of Jacob and all the families of the house of Israel.
Thus says Jehovah: / What iniquity did your fathers find in Me / That they went far away from Me / And walked after [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]vanity / And became vain?
verse.note: Referring to the idols. By worshipping idols, Israel made themselves vain, nothing.

verse.text: And they did not say, Where is Jehovah, / Who [xref]a[/xref]brought us up from the land of Egypt, / Who brought us through the wilderness, / Through a land of deserts and pits, / Through a land of drought and the shadow of death, / Through a land that no one passes through / And where no man dwells?
And I brought you into the [xref]a[/xref]land of the fruited field, / To eat its fruit and its goodness. / But you came and defiled My land / And made My inheritance an abomination.

The priests did not say, / Where is Jehovah? / And those who handle the law did not know Me, / And the shepherds transgressed against Me, / And the prophets prophesied by Baal / And followed after things that did not benefit [i]them.[/i]
Therefore I will yet contend with you, declares Jehovah; / And with your children's children I will contend.
For pass over to the coastlands of Kittim and see, / And send [i]someone[/i] to Kedar and consider carefully, / And see if there has [i]ever[/i] been [i]anything[/i] like this.

Has a nation [i]ever[/i] exchanged [i]its[/i] gods, / Even though they are [xref]a[/xref]no gods? / But My people have exchanged their [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]glory / For that which does not benefit [i]them.[/i]
verse.note: Israel exchanged the reality of their God, their glory, for the vanity of idols (cf. [link]Rom. 1:23-25[/link]).

verse.text: Be appalled at this, O heavens, / And be horrified; be very desolate, / Declares Jehovah.

For My people have committed two evils: / They have forsaken Me, / The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fountain of living waters, / To hew out for themselves [note]1[/note]cisterns, / Broken cisterns, / Which hold no water.
verse.note: Jeremiah, a book full of speaking concerning Israel's sin and God's wrath, chastisement, and punishment, reveals that God's intention in His economy is to be the fountain, the source, of living waters to dispense Himself into His chosen people for their satisfaction and enjoyment. The goal of this enjoyment is to produce the church, God's counterpart, as God's increase, God's enlargement, to be God's fullness for His expression ([link]John 3:29-30[/link]; [link]Eph. 3:16-19[/link], [link]21[/link]). This is the heart's desire, the good pleasure, of God in His economy ([link]Eph. 1:5[/link], [link]9[/link]; [link]3:9-11[/link]). The full development of this thought, sown as a seed in this verse, is in the New Testament ([link]John 4:10[/link], [link]14[/link]; [link]7:37-39[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 10:4[/link]; [link]12:13[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:1[/link], [link]17[/link]).[br][br]Israel should have drunk of God as the fountain of living waters that they might become His increase as His expression, but instead they committed two evils: they forsook God as their fountain, their source, and they turned to a source other than God. These two evils govern the entire book of Jeremiah. The hewing out of cisterns portrays Israel's toil in their human labor to make something (idols) to replace God. That the cisterns were broken and could hold no water indicates that apart from God Himself dispensed into us as living water, nothing can quench our thirst and make us God's increase for His expression ([link]John 4:13-14[/link]).

verse.text: Is Israel a slave? Is he a homeborn [i]slave?[/i] / Why has he become a prey?
The young lions roared over him; / They sounded their voices. / And they have made his land a waste; / His cities are burned, without inhabitant.
Also the children of Memphis and Tahpanhes / Have shaved the crown of your head.
Have you not done this to yourself / By your forsaking Jehovah your God / When He was leading you in the way?

And now what do you have on the road to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Egypt, / To drink the waters of the [note]2[/note]Shihor? / And what do you have on the road to [note]1[/note]Assyria, / To drink the waters of the [note]3[/note]River?
verse.note: Israel sought and trusted in the Egyptians' and Assyrians' help (man's help) instead of seeking and trusting in God's blessing ([link]vv. 17-18[/link], [link]36[/link]; [link]Isa. 31:3[/link]).
A reference to the Nile.
I.e., the Euphrates.

verse.text: Your own wickedness will correct you, / And your [note]1[/note]apostasies will reprove you. / Know therefore and see that it is an evil and bitter thing, / That you have forsaken Jehovah your God / And that My fear is not in you, / Declares the Lord Jehovah of hosts.
verse.note: Apostasy is a matter of leaving the way of God and taking another way to follow things other than God. It is to forsake God and turn to idols ([link]v. 13[/link]).

verse.text: For long ago you broke your yoke; / You tore off your bonds; / And you said, I will not serve! / Indeed upon every high hill / And under every flourishing tree / You have lain down, [i]you[/i] have committed [note]1[/note]fornication.
verse.note: As the wife of Jehovah, Israel forsook her chastity to commit fornication by worshipping idols. In doing this, she had a harlot's forehead and refused to be ashamed ([link]vv. 20[/link], [link]23-25[/link]; [link]3:1-3[/link]).

verse.text: Yet I, I had [xref]a[/xref]planted you as a choice [xref]b[/xref]vine, / Wholly a faithful seed. / How then have you turned yourself before Me / Into the degenerate shoots of a foreign vine?
For though you wash yourself with lye / And make use of much soap, / Your iniquity remains as a stain before Me, / Declares the Lord Jehovah.
How can you say, I am not defiled; / I have not gone after the Baals? / Look at your way in the valley; / Know what you have done. / [i]You are like[/i] a swift young camel entangling her ways,

[i]Like[/i] a wild donkey accustomed to the wilderness, / Panting after the wind in her desire. / In her passion who can turn her away? / None that seek her will weary themselves: / They will find her in her month.
Keep your foot from being unshod / And your throat from thirst; / But you said, It is hopeless. / No! For I have loved strangers, / And I will go after them.
As the thief is ashamed when he is found, / So the house of Israel is ashamed — / They, their kings, their princes, / And their priests and their prophets,

Who say to a tree, You are my father; / And to a stone, You have brought me forth — / For they have turned [i]their[/i] back to Me, / And not [i]their[/i] faces. / Yet in a time of their trouble they will say, / Arise and save us.

But where are your [xref]a[/xref]gods, whom you made for yourselves? / Let them arise, if they can save you in the time of your trouble; / For [xref]b[/xref][i]according to[/i] the number of your cities / Are your gods, O Judah.
Why do you contend with Me? / You have all transgressed against Me, / Declares Jehovah.
In vain I have stricken your children: / They have taken no correction. / Your own sword has devoured your [xref]a[/xref]prophets / Like a destroying lion.
O generation, attend to the word of Jehovah: / Have I been a wilderness to Israel, / Or a land of deep darkness? / Why do My people say, We roam about; / We will no longer come to You?
Can the virgin forget her [note]1[/note]ornaments, / Or the bride her [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]attire? / But My people have [xref]b[/xref]forgotten Me / For days [note]2[/note]without number.
verse.note: This word concerning ornaments and attire indicates that God is our ornament and attire, i.e., our beautification. Although God was Israel's beautification, Israel forgot Him.

Israel's forsaking of God for idols and their breaking of God's commandments began with the worshipping of the golden calf at Mount Sinai ([link]Exo. 32:1-6[/link]). Later, in his respeaking of the divine law Moses charged Israel especially that when they entered the good land, they were to tear down the idols, destroy the places of idol worship, and slaughter the idol worshippers ([link]Deut. 7:2[/link], [link]5[/link]). Israel, however, did not obey the commandment to utterly destroy the idol worshippers. As a result, Israel could not fully possess the good land, and there was war repeatedly between Israel and the people in the land. After David had fought all the inhabitants of the land and gained nearly the entire land, and Solomon, his son, had built the temple in about 1000 B.C., in his old age Solomon was led by his many heathen wives to worship idols ([link]1 Kings 11:1-8[/link]). Nearly all his descendants continued his apostasy. Eventually, Israel's worshipping of idols and their breaking of the law reached its peak at the time of Jeremiah. At that time Israel was in the sunset of the divine revelation. Cf. note [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in Judg. 2[/link].

verse.text: How you prepare your ways / To seek love! / Therefore you have even taught / Wicked women your ways.
Also on your skirts is found / The lifeblood of the innocent poor. / You did not find them breaking in, / But [i]killed them[/i] because of all these things.
But you said, I am innocent; / Surely His anger will turn from me. / I am about to enter into judgment with you, / Because you say, I have not sinned.
Why do you go about so much / To change your way? / You will be put to shame by Egypt also, / Even as you were put to shame by Assyria.
Indeed, from it you will go forth / With your hands upon your head; / For Jehovah has rejected those in whom you trust, / And you will not prosper by them.

It is said, / [xref]a[/xref]If a man divorces his wife / And she goes from him / And becomes another man's [i]wife,[/i] / Will he return to her again? / Will not that land be / Utterly polluted? / But you have committed fornication with many lovers. / [note]1[/note]Yet [xref]b[/xref]return to Me, declares Jehovah.
verse.note: In spite of Israel's fornication, which was like that of a divorced wife, Jehovah would return to her again if she would return to Him. This is Jehovah's compassions, which do not fail and are new every morning ([link]Lam. 3:22-23[/link]).

verse.text: Lift up your eyes to the bare heights and see: / Where have you not been ravished? / By the roads you sat for them, / Like an Arab in the desert; / And you have polluted the land / With your fornication and your wickedness.
Therefore the showers have been withheld, / And there has been no spring rain. / But you have had a harlot's forehead; / You refused to be ashamed.
Have you not just now called out to Me, My [xref]a[/xref]Father, / You are the guide of my youth?
Will He preserve [i]His anger[/i] forever? / Will He keep [i]it[/i] perpetually? / This you have spoken; yet you have done [i]what[/i] evil things / That you could.

Then Jehovah said to me in the days of Josiah the king, Have you seen what [note]1[/note]Israel the apostate has done? She went up on every high mountain and under every flourishing tree and committed fornication there.
verse.note: Israel had been divided into two kingdoms, the north being called the kingdom of Israel and the south, the kingdom of Judah ([link]1 Kings 11:9-12:24[/link]). The northern kingdom of Israel became apostate and committed spiritual fornication (adultery) with idols ([link]vv. 6, 9[/link]). Because of this, Jehovah divorced her ([link]v. 8a[/link]). Israel's treacherous sister, Judah, saw what Israel did and how she was punished for the evil thing she did. However, Judah did not fear but committed fornication also ([link]vv. 7b[/link], [link]8b[/link]).

verse.text: And I said, After she has done all these things, she will return to Me; but she did not return, and her treacherous [xref]a[/xref]sister Judah saw it.

And I saw that because of all the adultery that Israel the apostate committed I divorced her and gave her a certificate of divorce, yet her sister Judah the treacherous did not fear but went and committed fornication also.
And because she treated her fornication lightly, she polluted the land and committed adultery with stones and trees.
And yet in spite of all this her treacherous sister Judah did not return to Me with all her heart, but instead falsely, declares Jehovah.
And Jehovah said to me, Israel the apostate has shown herself to be more righteous than Judah the treacherous.

Go and proclaim these words to the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]north, and say, / [note]2[/note]Return, O Israel the apostate, declares Jehovah; / [i]And[/i] I will not let My countenance fall toward you; / For I am merciful, declares Jehovah; / [xref]b[/xref]I will not keep [i]My anger[/i] forever.
verse.note: Referring to Assyria, to which Israel had been carried away ([link]2 Kings 18:9-12[/link]).
[link]Jeremiah 3:12-4:2[/link] is a loving pleading of Jehovah the Husband for Israel to return to Him.

verse.text: Only [xref]a[/xref]acknowledge your iniquity, / That you have transgressed against Jehovah your God / And have turned your ways here and there to strangers under every / flourishing tree, / And have not listened to My voice, declares Jehovah.
Return, O apostate children, declares Jehovah, for I am a [xref]a[/xref]Husband to you; and I will take you, one from a city and two from a family, and will bring you to Zion.
And I will give you [xref]a[/xref]shepherds according to My own heart, who will feed you knowledge and understanding.

And when you are multiplied and increased in the land, in those days, declares Jehovah, they will no longer say, The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Ark of the Covenant of Jehovah! And it will not come to mind, nor will they remember it or visit [i]it;[/i] and it will not be made again.
verse.note: At the time of restoration promised by God in [link]vv. 16-18[/link], Israel will no longer care for the Ark of the Covenant as God's meeting place with her because Christ, the embodiment of God, will be present with her and will reign in Jerusalem. See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Sam. 4[/link].

verse.text: At that time they will call Jerusalem the [xref]a[/xref]throne of Jehovah, and all the nations will be [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]gathered to it because the name of Jehovah is at Jerusalem; and they will no longer walk after the stubbornness of their evil heart.
verse.note: In the restoration in the millennium ([link]Matt. 19:28[/link]), Jehovah as Christ will be the King reigning over Israel, and all the nations will be gathered to Jerusalem ([link]Isa. 2:2-3[/link]; [link]60:3-5[/link]; [link]Zech. 8:20-23[/link]).

verse.text: In those days the house of [note]1[/note]Judah will walk with the house of [note]1[/note]Israel, and they will come together from the land of the [xref]a[/xref]north to the land which I have given to their fathers as an inheritance.
verse.note: In the restoration the twelve tribes of Israel will no longer be divided but will be one.

verse.text: But I said, / How I will put you among the sons, / And give you a pleasant land, / An inheritance of the most ornate of the nations! / And I said, You will call Me, My [xref]a[/xref]Father, / And will not turn away from Me.
Surely as a woman acts treacherously [i]by departing[/i] from her husband, / So you have dealt treacherously with Me, O house of Israel, declares / Jehovah.
A voice is heard on the bare heights, / The weeping, the supplications, of the children of Israel; / For they have perverted their way; / They have forgotten Jehovah their God.
[xref]a[/xref]Return, O apostate children; / I will heal you of your apostasies. / Now we come to You, / For You are Jehovah our God.
Surely in vain [i]have we hoped for[/i] [xref]a[/xref][i]anything[/i] from the hills; / The mountains are a tumult; / Surely in Jehovah our God / Is the salvation of Israel.
But shame has devoured the labor of our fathers since our youth, their flocks and their herds, their sons and their daughters.

Let us lie down in our shame, and let our humiliation cover us; for we have sinned against Jehovah our God, we and our fathers, since our youth even unto this day; and we have not listened to the voice of Jehovah our God.
If you will return, O Israel, declares Jehovah, / [xref]a[/xref]Return to Me; / And if you put away your detestable things from My presence / And do not wander,
And swear, As Jehovah lives, / In truth and in justice and in righteousness, / Then the nations will [xref]a[/xref]bless themselves in Him, / And in Him they will glory.
For thus says Jehovah to the men of Judah and to Jerusalem, / Break up your [note]1[/note]fallow ground, / And do not [xref]a[/xref]sow among thorns.
verse.note: Israel should sow everything in the presence of God, with God, and for God. This is to use the land properly. Instead they worshipped idols and sowed among thorns. Thus, God advised them to stop that kind of sowing and return to the fallow ground in which they should have been sowing.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Circumcise yourselves to Jehovah, / And remove the foreskins of your heart, / Men of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem, / Lest My wrath go forth like fire / And burn, and there be no one to quench it / Because of the evil of your deeds.
Declare in Judah / And proclaim in Jerusalem, and say: / Blow the trumpet in the land; / Cry aloud and say, / Gather yourselves and let us go / Into the fortified cities.
Raise up a standard toward Zion. / Seek refuge; [xref]a[/xref]do not stay; / For I am bringing evil from the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]north, / And great destruction.
verse.note: Referring to Babylon.

verse.text: A [note]1[/note]lion has come up from his thicket, / And a destroyer of nations has set out. / He has gone forth from his place / To make your land a waste; / Your cities will be ruins, / Without an inhabitant.
verse.note: Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon.

verse.text: For this, gird yourselves with sackcloth, / Wail and howl; / For the burning anger of Jehovah / Has not turned away from us.
And in that day, declares Jehovah, the heart of the king and the heart of the princes will fail; and the priests will be appalled, and the prophets will be astounded.
And I said, Alas, Lord Jehovah, surely You have utterly deceived this people and Jerusalem, saying, You will have peace; whereas the sword reaches to the soul.
At that time it will be said to this people and to Jerusalem, A hot wind from the bare heights in the wilderness toward the daughter of My people, not for winnowing nor for purging
(A wind too strong for these), will come [note]1[/note]from Me; now I will also utter judgments against them.
verse.note: Or, for Me; i.e., for My sake.

verse.text: Here he is coming up like clouds, / And his chariots like the whirlwind; / His horses are swifter than [xref]a[/xref]eagles. / Woe to us for we are devastated!
[xref]a[/xref]Wash your heart from wickedness, O Jerusalem, / That you may be saved. / How long will your evil thoughts / Lodge within you?
For a voice declares from Dan / And announces affliction from the hill country of Ephraim.
Make mention to the nations; yes, / Announce against Jerusalem. / Besiegers are coming from a distant land / And utter their voice against the cities of Judah.
Like those who watch over a field, they are against her all around / Because she has rebelled against Me, declares Jehovah.
Your way and your deeds / Have caused these things [i]to happen[/i] to you. / This is your wickedness. Indeed it is bitter! / Indeed it reaches to your heart!

My bowels, my bowels; I am writhing. / Oh, the walls of my heart! / My [xref]a[/xref]heart is moaning within me; / I cannot be silent; / For you hear, O my soul, the sound of the [xref]b[/xref]trumpet, / The alarm of war.
Destruction upon destruction is proclaimed, / For the whole land is devastated. / Suddenly my tents are devastated, / [i]And[/i] my curtains in a moment.
How long will I see the standard, / [i]And[/i] hear the sound of the trumpet?
For My people are foolish; / They do not know Me. / They are stupid children / And have no understanding. / They are wise to do evil, / But they do not know to do good.
I looked at the [xref]a[/xref]earth, and there it was, [xref]b[/xref]waste and emptiness; / And at the heavens, and they had no light.
I looked at the mountains, and there they were, shaking, / And all the hills were swaying.
I looked, and there was [xref]a[/xref]no man, / And all the birds of the heavens had fled.
I looked, and there was the fruitful land, a wilderness, / And all its cities were torn down / Before Jehovah, before His burning anger.
For thus says Jehovah, / The whole land will be a desolation, / But I will not make a [xref]a[/xref]full end;
For this the earth will mourn, / And the heavens above will be dark; / Because I have spoken, I have purposed; / And I have not repented, nor will I turn from it.
At the sound of horsemen and archers / Every city flees; / They go into the thickets / And climb up on the rocks. / Every city is forsaken, / And not even one inhabits them.

And you, O desolate one, what will you do? / Although you dress in scarlet, / Although you are adorned with ornaments of gold,[br/]Although you enlarge your [xref]a[/xref]eyes with paint, / In vain do you beautify yourself; / [i]Your[/i] lovers despise you; / They seek your life.

For I heard a cry like that of a [xref]a[/xref]woman in travail, / Anguish like that of a woman bringing forth her first child, / The sound of the daughter of Zion gasping for breath; / She stretches out her hands, [i]saying,[/i] / Woe is me, / For my soul is fainting before murderers.

[note]1[/note]Go to and fro in the streets of Jerusalem, / And look now and know, / And seek in her open squares / If you can find [xref]a[/xref]a man, / If there is anyone who executes justice, / Who seeks faithfulness; / And I will pardon her.
verse.note: [link]Chapters 2-4[/link] are Jehovah the Husband's major complaint against Israel the wife's apostasy, her spiritual fornication, her worshipping and making idols. By worshipping idols, Israel broke the first four commandments of the law ([link]Exo. 20:1-11[/link]), which concern her relationship with God. [link]Chapters 5-6[/link] are Jehovah the Husband's further complaint against Israel (actually Judah) the wife's wickednesses in detail. The details concerning her evil conduct show that she also broke the last five commandments of the law ([link]Exo. 20:13-17[/link]), those concerning man's relationship with man.

verse.text: And although they say, As Jehovah lives, / Nevertheless they swear falsely.

O Jehovah, are not Your eyes upon faithfulness? / You have stricken them, / But they did not writhe; / You have consumed them, / But they refused to take correction. / They have made their faces harder than rock; / They have refused to turn.
Then I said, But they are the poor; / They are foolish; / For they do not know the way of Jehovah, / The [note]1[/note]ordinance of their God.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 4[/link].

verse.text: I will go to the great / And speak with them; / Surely these know the way of Jehovah, / The ordinance of their God. / But together they [i]both[/i] have broken the yoke; / They have torn off the bonds.

Therefore a lion from the forest will strike them; / A wolf of the [note]1[/note]deserts will destroy them. / A leopard is watching their cities; / Everyone who goes out from them will be torn in pieces; / Because they multiplied their transgressions, / And their apostasies are great in number.
verse.note: Or, evenings.

verse.text: Why should I pardon you? / Your children have forsaken Me / And sworn by those who are [xref]a[/xref]not gods. / When I fed them to the full, they committed adultery / And trooped to the house of harlots.
[i]Like[/i] well-fed horses they roam about, / Each one neighing after his neighbor's wife.
[xref]a[/xref]Shall I not [note]1[/note]punish because of these things? / Declares Jehovah; / And on a nation such as this / Shall My soul not avenge itself?
verse.note: Lit., visit (i.e., for punishment). So throughout the book.

verse.text: Go up through her vine rows and destroy, / But do not make a [xref]a[/xref]full end; / Strip away her [xref]b[/xref]branches, / For they are not Jehovah's.
For the house of Israel and the house of Judah / Have dealt very treacherously with Me, declares Jehovah.
They have denied Jehovah / And have said, He is not; / And evil will not come upon us, / Nor will we see sword and famine;
And the prophets will become wind, / And [note]1[/note]the word is not in them; / Thus it will be done to them.
verse.note: Following the Septuagint; the Masoretic text reads, He who speaks.

verse.text: Therefore thus says Jehovah / The God of hosts: / Because [note]1[/note]they have spoken this word, / I am now making My [xref]a[/xref]words / A fire in your mouth, / And this people wood; / And it will consume them.
verse.note: Lit., you.

verse.text: I am now bringing upon you / A nation from [xref]a[/xref]afar, / O house of Israel, declares Jehovah. / It is an enduring nation, / It is an ancient nation; / A nation whose language you do not know, / Nor can you understand what they say.
Their quiver is like an open grave; / All of them are mighty men.

And they will eat up your [xref]a[/xref]harvest and your bread; / They will eat up your sons and your daughters; / They will eat up your flocks and your herds; / They will eat up your vines and your fig trees; / They will demolish with the sword your fortified cities, / In which you trust.
Yet even in those days, declares Jehovah, I will not make a [xref]a[/xref]full end of you.

And when [note]1[/note]they say, Why has Jehovah our God done all these things to us? you shall say to them, As you have forsaken Me and served foreign gods in your land, so you will serve strangers in a land that is not yours.
verse.note: Lit., you.

verse.text: Declare this in the house of Jacob, / And announce it in the house of Judah, saying,
Now hear this, / O people, who are foolish and without understanding, / Who have [xref]a[/xref]eyes but do not see, / Who have ears but do not hear:

Do you not fear Me, declares Jehovah; / Do you not tremble at My presence; / Who have set the sand as a [xref]a[/xref]boundary for the sea / By an eternal statute, so it cannot pass over it? / Although its waves toss, they cannot prevail; / Although they roar, they cannot pass over it.
But this people has a stubborn and rebellious heart; / They have turned aside and have gone away.

And they do not say in their heart, / Let us now fear Jehovah our God, who gives us [xref]a[/xref]rain, / Both [note]1[/note]the early rain and the late rain, in its season, / Who preserves the appointed weeks of the harvest for us.
verse.note: I.e., the autumn rain and the spring rain.

verse.text: Your iniquities have turned these things away, / And your sins have withheld from you what is good.
For wicked men are found among My people; / They lie in wait like fowlers crouching; / They set a trap, / They catch men.
Like a cage full of birds, / So their houses are full of deceit; / Therefore they have become great and rich.
They are fat; they are sleek; / Indeed they surpass in deeds of wickedness; / They do not judge the cause, / The cause of the orphan, but they prosper; / And the right of the needy they do not judge.
[xref]a[/xref]Shall I not punish because of these things? / Declares Jehovah; / And on a nation such as this / Shall My soul not avenge itself?
An appalling and horrible thing / Has happened in the land:
The prophets prophesy [xref]a[/xref]falsely, / And the priests rule by their own [note]1[/note]authority; / And My people love it this way. / But what will you do at the end of it?
verse.note: The priests actually were judges (see note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 17[/link]), and they should have judged the cases of the people according to God's law. However, they judged, ruled, by their own authority, i.e., according to their opinion. The people loved it this way. This may indicate that the people were bribing the priests.

verse.text: Seek refuge, O children of Benjamin, / From the midst of Jerusalem; / And blow the trumpet in Tekoa / And raise up a signal on [note]1[/note]Beth-haccerem; / For evil looks down from the [note]2[/note]north, / And great destruction.
verse.note: Or, the vineyard house.
Cf. note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: The comely and delicate one, / The daughter of Zion, I will cut off.
Shepherds will come to her / With their flocks; / They will pitch tents against her all around; / They will feed each one in his place.
[note]1[/note]Prepare war against her; / Rise up, and let us go up at noon. / Woe to us, for the day has declined, / For the shadows of evening are lengthening.
verse.note: In [link]vv. 4-5[/link] God speaks to the Babylonians; He would use them in His correcting of Israel.

verse.text: Rise up, and let us go up at night / And destroy her palaces.
For thus says Jehovah of hosts, / Cut down her trees and build up / A [xref]a[/xref]mound against Jerusalem. / This is the city to be punished; / In her midst there is only oppression.
As a cistern keeps its waters fresh, / So she has kept her wickedness fresh. / Violence and destruction are heard in her; / Sickness and wounds are always before Me.
Be admonished, O Jerusalem, / Lest My [xref]a[/xref]desire for you depart, / Lest I make you a desolation, / An uninhabited land.
Thus says Jehovah of hosts, / They will thoroughly [note]1[/note]glean like a vine / The remnant of Israel; / Pass your hand again over the branches / Like a grape gatherer.
verse.note: According to God's law, once the grapes were harvested, no one was allowed to pick the gleanings, for the remnant of the grape harvest was to be for the poor ([link]Lev. 19:9-10[/link]). However, the Babylonians would harvest the "grapes" from the "vine" of Israel, and then come again to glean the vine thoroughly. This means that they would come more than once to take the people captive ([link]52:28-30[/link]).

verse.text: To whom shall I speak and testify, / That they may hear? / Indeed, their [xref]a[/xref]ear is uncircumcised, / And they are unable to listen. / See, the word of Jehovah has become a reproach to them; / They have no delight in it.

Yet I am full of the wrath of Jehovah; / I am weary of [xref]a[/xref]holding it in. / Pour it out upon the children in the street / And upon the assembly of the young men together; / For even the husband with the wife will be taken; / The old man, with the one who is full of days.
[xref]a[/xref]And their houses will be turned over to others, / Fields and wives together; / For I will stretch out My hand / Over the inhabitants of the land, / Declares Jehovah.
For from the least of them to the greatest of them, / Everyone is wresting unjust gain; / And from the prophet to the priest, / Everyone is dealing falsely.
[xref]a[/xref]And they have healed / The brokenness of My people slightly, / Saying, [xref]b[/xref]Peace, peace; / Although there is no peace.

Were they ashamed when they committed abomination? / They were not at all ashamed; / They did not even know to blush. / Therefore they will fall with those who fall; / At the time I punish them, they will stumble, / Says Jehovah.

Thus says Jehovah, / Stand by the ways and see, / And ask for the ancient paths; / [i]Ask[/i] where the good way is, and walk in it; / And you will find [xref]a[/xref]rest for your souls. / But they said, We will not walk [i]in it.[/i]
So I set watchmen over you, [i]saying,[/i] / Listen to the sound of the trumpet. / But they said, We will not listen.
Therefore hear, O nations, / And understand, O assembly, / What [i]I will do[/i] to them.
Listen, O earth; I am now bringing evil / On this people, / The fruit of their thoughts; / Because they have not listened to My words, / And they have also rejected My law.
For what purpose does frankincense come to Me from Sheba, / And sweet cane from a distant land? / Your [xref]a[/xref]burnt offerings are not acceptable, / And your sacrifices are not pleasing to Me.
Therefore thus says Jehovah, / I am now laying before this people stumbling blocks, / And fathers and sons together / Will stumble against them; / A neighbor and his friend will perish.
Thus says Jehovah, / [xref]a[/xref]See, a people is coming from the land of the [xref]b[/xref]north, / And a great nation is stirring from the uttermost parts of the earth.
They grasp bow and spear; / They are cruel and have no mercy; / Their voice roars like the sea; / And they ride upon horses, / Set in array as a man for battle / Against you, O daughter of Zion.
We have heard its report; / Our hands are feeble; / Distress has seized us, / Pain like a [xref]a[/xref]woman in childbirth.
Do not go out into the field, / And do not walk on the road; / For the enemy has a sword; / Terror is on every side.
O daughter of my people, gird yourself in sackcloth / And roll in ashes; / [xref]a[/xref]Mourn [i]as[/i] for an only son, / A most bitter wailing; / For suddenly the destroyer / Will come upon us.
I have set you as a trier among My people, as a fortress, / That you may know and try their way.
All of them are most rebellious, / Going about as slanderers; / They are bronze and iron; / All of them act corruptly.
The bellows are burned; / The lead is consumed by the fire; / The refining continues in vain, / For the wicked are not removed.
[i]Men[/i] will call them rejected silver, / Because Jehovah has rejected them.
The word that came to Jeremiah from Jehovah, saying,
Stand in the gate of the house of Jehovah, and proclaim this word there and say, Hear the word of Jehovah, all Judah, who enter through these gates to worship Jehovah.
Thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, [xref]a[/xref]Amend your ways and your deeds, and I will cause you to dwell in this place.
Do not trust in the words of falsehood that say, The [note]1[/note]temple of Jehovah, the temple of Jehovah, these [i]buildings[/i] are the temple of Jehovah.
verse.note: Israel's (actually Judah's — [link]7:21[/link]; [link]9:26[/link]) hypocritical worship of Jehovah their God was a false worship and was a worship of superstition. In their superstitious worship, even the temple had become an idol and something of superstition. Thus, Jeremiah told them not to say these words regarding the temple of Jehovah. Cf. note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Sam. 4[/link].

verse.text: But if you truly amend your ways and your deeds, if you truly execute justice between a man and his neighbor,
[i]If[/i] you do not [note]1[/note]oppress the sojourner, the orphan, and the widow, and do not shed innocent blood in this place, nor go after other gods to your own ruin;
verse.note: As the hypocritical worshippers of God, Israel (actually Judah) committed many evils ([link]vv. 6[/link], [link]9[/link], [link]18[/link], [link]23-26[/link], [link]28[/link], [link]30-31[/link]; [link]8:5-10[/link], [link]19[/link]; [link]9:2-5[/link], [link]8[/link], [link]26[/link]). Israel was corrupt in every way, in relation to God and to one another.

verse.text: Then I will cause you to dwell in this place, in the land which I gave to your fathers from eternity to eternity.
See, you are trusting in words of falsehood that do not benefit [i]you.[/i]
Will you [xref]a[/xref]steal, murder, and commit adultery, and swear falsely, and burn incense to Baal and go after other gods which you have not known,
Then come and stand before Me in this house, which is called by My name, and say, We are delivered! — that you may do all these abominations?
Has this [xref]a[/xref]house which is called by My name become a den of [xref]b[/xref]robbers in your eyes? Yet I, even I, have seen it, declares Jehovah.
But go now to My place which was in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Shiloh, where I caused My name to dwell at first, and see [xref]b[/xref]what I did to it because of the wickedness of My people Israel.
verse.note: Shiloh, where the house of God was first set up in the land of Canaan ([link]Josh. 18:1[/link]), was defeated and destroyed because of the wickedness of Israel ([link]vv. 12-14[/link]; [link]26:6a[/link], [link]9a[/link]; [link]1 Sam. 4:4[/link], [link]10-11[/link]).

verse.text: And now, because you have done all these works, declares Jehovah, and I spoke to you, [xref]a[/xref]rising up early and speaking, but you did not listen, and I called you, but you did not answer;
Therefore I will do to the house that is called by My name, in which you trust, and to the place that I gave you and your fathers as I have done to [xref]a[/xref]Shiloh.
And I will cast you out from before Me, as I cast out all your brothers, all the seed of Ephraim.
[xref]a[/xref]And as for you, do not pray for this people, nor lift up a ringing cry or a prayer for them; and do not intercede with Me, for I will not hear you.
Do you not see what they are doing in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem?

The children gather wood, and the fathers light the fire, and the women knead the dough, to make cakes for the [note]1[/note]queen of heaven and to pour out drink offerings to other gods to provoke Me to anger.
verse.note: Nimrod's wife Semiramis, later known as Artemis in Ephesus ([link]Acts 19:27[/link]). Israel's making cakes for the wife of Nimrod was a matter of both spiritual fornication and idolatry.

verse.text: Are they provoking Me to anger? declares Jehovah. [i]Are they[/i] not [i]provoking[/i] themselves, to the shaming of their own faces?

Therefore thus says the Lord Jehovah, My anger and My wrath will be poured out on this place, on man and on beast and on the trees of the field and on the fruit of the ground; and it will burn and not be quenched.
Thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, Add your burnt offerings to your sacrifices and eat the flesh.
For I did not speak to your fathers or command them in the day that I brought them out of the land of Egypt concerning burnt offerings and sacrifices.

But this is what I commanded them, saying, [xref]a[/xref]Hear My voice, and [xref]b[/xref]I will be your God, and you will be My people; and walk in all the way which I command you, that it may go well with you.
But they did not listen or incline their ear, but walked in the counsels and the stubbornness of their evil hearts and went backward and not forward.
From the day that your fathers came out from the land of Egypt unto this day I have [xref]a[/xref]sent to you all My servants the prophets, daily rising up early and sending [i]them.[/i]
But they did not listen to Me or incline their ear, but stiffened their neck; they did more evil than their fathers.
So you shall speak to them all these words, but they will not listen to you; and you shall call to them, but they will not answer you.
And you shall say to them, This is the nation which did not listen to the voice of Jehovah their God and did not take correction; the truth has perished and is cut off from their mouth.
[xref]a[/xref]Cut off your [note]1[/note]hair and throw it away, / And take up a lamentation on the bare heights; / For Jehovah has rejected and forsaken / The generation of His overflowing wrath.
verse.note: Cf. note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in Num. 6[/link].

verse.text: For the children of Judah have done that which is evil in My sight, declares Jehovah; [xref]a[/xref]they have set their detestable things in the [xref]b[/xref]house which is called by My name, to defile it.

And they have built the high places of [xref]a[/xref]Topheth, which is in the valley of the son of Hinnom, to burn their sons and their daughters in the fire, something I did not command, nor did it come up in My heart.

Therefore, days are coming, declares Jehovah, when it will no longer be called Topheth, or the valley of the son of Hinnom, but the valley of slaughter; for they will bury in Topheth because there will be no [i]other[/i] place.
And the corpses of this people will become food for the [xref]a[/xref]birds of the sky and for the beasts of the earth; and no one will frighten [i]them[/i] away.

And I will cause the [xref]a[/xref]voice of gladness and the voice of joy to cease, the voice of the bridegroom and the voice of the bride, from the cities of Judah and from the streets of Jerusalem; for the land will become a waste.

At that time, declares Jehovah, they will bring out the bones of the kings of Judah and the bones of its princes and the bones of the priests and the bones of the prophets and the bones of the inhabitants of Jerusalem from their graves.

And they will spread them out to the sun and to the moon and to all the host of heaven, which they have loved and which they have served and which they have gone after and which they have sought and which they have worshipped; and they will not be gathered up or [xref]a[/xref]buried; they will be like dung on the surface of the ground.
And [xref]a[/xref]death will be chosen rather than life by all the remnant that remains of this evil family, that remains in all the places where I have driven them, declares Jehovah of hosts.
And you shall say to them, Thus says Jehovah,[br/]Do [i]men[/i] fall and not rise again? / If one turns away, does he not return?
Why has this people Jerusalem / Turned away in perpetual apostasy? / They hold fast to deceit; / They refuse to turn back.

I have listened carefully and heard; / They have not spoken rightly; / There is no one who [xref]a[/xref]repents of his wickedness, / Saying, What have I done? / Everyone turns to his own course, / Like a horse rushing headlong into battle.
Even the stork in the sky / Knows its appointed times, / And the turtledove and the swallow and the crane / Keep the time of their coming; / But My people do not know / The ordinance of Jehovah.
How can you say, We are wise, / And the law of Jehovah is with us? / But look, the false pen of the scribes / Has turned [i]it[/i] into falsehood.
The [xref]a[/xref]wise men are put to shame; / They are dismayed and are taken;[br/]See, they have rejected the word of Jehovah; / And what wisdom do they have?

[xref]a[/xref]Therefore I will [xref]b[/xref]give their wives to others, / Their fields to those who will possess [i]them;[/i] / For from the small unto the great, / Everyone is wresting unjust gain; / From the prophet even to the priest, / Everyone is dealing falsely.
And they have healed / The brokenness of the daughter of My people slightly, / Saying, Peace, peace, / Although there is no peace.

Were they ashamed when they committed abomination? / They were not at all ashamed; / They did not even know to blush. / Therefore they will fall with those who fall; / At the time of their [note]1[/note]punishment they will stumble, / Says Jehovah.
verse.note: Lit., visitation (i.e., for punishment). So throughout the book.

verse.text: I will utterly take them away, / Declares Jehovah; / There are no grapes on the vine, / And there are [xref]a[/xref]no figs on the fig tree; / Even the leaves are withered; / And what I gave them has passed away from them.

Why do we sit? Gather yourselves, / And let us go up to the fortified cities / And be silent there, / Because Jehovah our God has silenced us / And made us drink poisonous water, / Because we have sinned against Jehovah.
[xref]a[/xref]We hoped for peace, but no good [i]came;[/i] / For a time of healing, but there was terror.

The snorting of their horses / Is heard from Dan; / At the sound of the neighing of their stallions / The whole land quakes. / And they come and devour the land and its fullness, / The city and those who dwell in it.
For I will send among you [xref]a[/xref]serpents, / Adders, for which there is no enchantment; / And they will bite you, / Declares Jehovah.
Oh [i]that there were[/i] comforting to me in sorrow! / My heart within me is faint.

It is the voice of the cry of the daughter of my people / From a land very [xref]a[/xref]far away: / Is Jehovah not in [xref]b[/xref]Zion? / Is her [xref]c[/xref]King not in her? / Why have they provoked Me to [xref]d[/xref]anger / With their graven images [i]and[/i] with strange idols?
The harvest has passed, the summer has ended, / And we are not saved.
For the brokenness of the daughter of my people I am broken. / I [xref]a[/xref]mourn; horror has taken hold of me.
Is there no [xref]a[/xref]balm in Gilead? / Is there no physician there? / Why then has the recovery of the daughter of my people / Not occurred?
Oh that my head were waters, / And my eye a fountain of tears, / That I might [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]weep day and night / For the slain of the daughter of my people!
verse.note: Jehovah came in to correct His hypocritical worshippers, and Jeremiah reacted to Jehovah's correction of Israel ([link]8:18-19[/link], [link]21-22[/link]; [link]9:1-2[/link]; [link]10:19-25[/link]). The prophet's reaction was very tender, sympathetic, and compassionate.[br][br]According to this book, God's love is a composition of His tender care, compassion, and sympathy. Even while He chastises His elect people Israel, He is compassionate toward them ([link]Lam. 3:22-23[/link]). In His chastising of Israel, God can be compared to a father who weeps as he disciplines his child because he loves the child. In this book Jeremiah wept on God's behalf; his weeping expressed God's feeling. We may say that God wept within Jeremiah's weeping, for in his weeping Jeremiah was one with God. Because Jeremiah often wept ([link]13:17[/link]; [link]Lam. 2:11[/link]; [link]3:48[/link]), even wailed, he is called the weeping prophet.

verse.text: Oh that I had a traveler's lodging place in the wilderness / That I might leave my people and go away from them, / For all of them are adulterers [i]and[/i] an assembly of treacherous men.
They bend their tongue [i]like[/i] their bow; / Falsehood, and not truth, / Prevails in the land; / For they proceed from evil to evil, / And they do [xref]a[/xref]not know Me, declares Jehovah.
Let each man be on guard against his neighbor / And not confide in any brother; / For every brother only supplants, / And every neighbor goes about as a slanderer.
And everyone deceives his neighbor / And does not speak the truth; / They teach their tongue to speak falsehood; / They weary themselves committing iniquity.
Your dwelling is in the midst of deceit; / Through deceit they refuse to know Me, / Declares Jehovah.
Therefore thus says Jehovah of hosts, / Indeed, I will [xref]a[/xref]refine them and test them; / For what else can I do because of the daughter of My people?
Their tongue is a deadly arrow; / It speaks deceit. / [i]Each[/i] speaks peaceably to his neighbor with his mouth, / But in his heart he lays an ambush for him.
[xref]a[/xref]Shall I not punish them for these things? / Declares Jehovah; / And on a nation such as this / Shall My soul not avenge itself?

For the mountains I will take up a [note]1[/note]weeping and wailing, / And for the pastures of the wilderness, a lamentation; / Because they have been burned up so that no one passes through, / And the sound of cattle is not heard; / Both the birds of the sky and the beasts / Have fled [i]and[/i] have gone.
verse.note: The words in [link]vv. 10-11[/link] and [link]17-19[/link] express Jehovah's feeling concerning Israel's suffering of His correction. Although Jehovah was punishing Israel, He was still sympathetic toward them. See note [link]18[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And I will make Jerusalem a [xref]a[/xref]heap of ruins, / A habitation of jackals; / And I will make the cities of Judah / A desolation without inhabitant.

Who is the wise man who can understand this, and he to whom the mouth of Jehovah has spoken, that he might declare it? Why is the land destitute, burned like the wilderness, so that no one passes through?
And Jehovah said, Because they have forsaken My law, which I set before them, and have not listened to My voice or walked in [note]1[/note]My law,
verse.note: Lit., it.

verse.text: But have walked after the stubbornness of their heart and after the Baals, as their fathers taught them;
Therefore thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, I will feed them, this people, with [xref]a[/xref]wormwood and give them poisonous water to drink.
And I will [xref]a[/xref]scatter them among the nations, whom neither they nor their fathers knew, and send the sword after them until I have consumed them.
Thus says Jehovah of hosts, / Consider, and call for the mourning women to come, / And send for the skillful women to come;
Let them hasten and take up a wailing for [note]1[/note]us, / That [note]1[/note]our eyes may shed tears / And [note]1[/note]our eyelids may pour forth water.
verse.note: The words [i]us[/i] and [i]our[/i] here indicate that Jehovah joined Himself to the suffering people and was one with them in their suffering. The sympathetic God who punished was also among His punished people. Eventually, those who wailed were wailing not only for Israel but also for Jehovah. Jehovah Himself was weeping in sympathy for His people. Cf. note [link]1[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: For a voice of wailing / Was heard from Zion:[br/]How we are ruined! / We are utterly put to shame! / For we have forsaken the land / Because they have cast down our dwellings.
Therefore listen, O women, to the word of Jehovah, / And let your ear receive the word of His mouth; / And teach your daughters wailing, / And [i]let[/i] each [i]teach[/i] her neighbor a lamentation.
For death has come up through our windows; / It has entered our palaces / To cut off the children from the streets, / The young men from the open squares.
Speak: Thus declares Jehovah, / And the corpses of men will fall / Like dung on the surface of the field / And like a sheaf after the reaper, / And there will be no one to gather [i]them.[/i]
Thus says Jehovah, / Let not the wise man [xref]a[/xref]glory in his wisdom, / And let not the mighty man glory in his might; / Let not the rich man glory in his riches.

But let him who glories glory in this, / That he has insight and knows Me, / That I am Jehovah who exercises lovingkindness, / Justice, and righteousness on earth; / For in these things I delight, declares Jehovah.
Indeed, days are coming, declares Jehovah, when I will punish all those who are [note]1[/note]circumcised [i]and[/i] yet [note]1[/note]uncircumcised:
verse.note: Israel had been circumcised physically, on their body ([link]Josh. 5:2-9[/link]), but not psychologically, in their inner being, in their heart ([link]4:4a[/link]; [link]Acts 7:51[/link]; cf. [link]Rom. 2:28-29[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:3[/link]).

verse.text: Egypt and Judah and Edom and the children of Ammon and Moab and all those who cut the corners [i]of their beards,[/i] who inhabit the wilderness; for all the nations are uncircumcised, and all the house of Israel is [xref]a[/xref]uncircumcised in heart.
Hear the word which Jehovah speaks to you, O house of Israel.
Thus says Jehovah, / Do not learn the way of the nations, / And do not be terrified by the [xref]a[/xref]signs of the heavens, / Although the nations are terrified by them.
For the customs of the peoples are vanity, / Because [i]their god is[/i] a tree cut from the forest, / The work of the [xref]a[/xref]hands of a craftsman with an ax.
He adorns it with silver and with gold; / They fasten it with nails and hammers / So that it cannot totter.

They are like a [note]1[/note]post in a cucumber field, / And they cannot speak; / They must be carried / Because they cannot walk. / Do not be afraid of them, / For they cannot do evil, / And neither is it in them to do good.
verse.note: I.e., as a scarecrow.

verse.text: There is [xref]a[/xref]none like You, O Jehovah; / You are great, / And Your name is great in might.
Who would not fear You, / O [xref]a[/xref]King of the nations? / For it befits You, / For among all the wise of the nations / And in all their kingdoms / There is none like You.
But they are altogether stupid and foolish; / The instruction of [i]their[/i] idols is [i]mere[/i] wood.

Beaten silver / Is brought from Tarshish, / And gold from Uphaz, / The work of a craftsman / And of the hands of a goldsmith. / Their clothing is blue and purple; / All of them are the work of skillful men.
But Jehovah is the true God; / He is the [xref]a[/xref]living God and the eternal [xref]b[/xref]King. / At His wrath the earth quakes, / And the nations cannot endure His indignation.
[note]1[/note]Thus you shall say to them, The gods that did not make the heavens and the earth, these will perish from the earth and from under the heavens.
verse.note: This verse is in Aramaic, not Hebrew.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]It is He who made the [xref]b[/xref]earth by His power, / Who established the [xref]c[/xref]world by His wisdom, / And by His understanding He stretched out the [xref]d[/xref]heavens.

When He utters His voice, there is a tumult of waters in the heavens, / [xref]a[/xref]And He causes the vapors to rise from the ends of the earth; / He makes lightning for the rain / And brings forth wind from His treasuries.
Every man is stupid, without knowledge; / Every goldsmith is put to shame by [i]his[/i] idol; / For his molten image is falsehood, / And there is no breath in them.
They are vanity, the work of delusion; / At the time of their punishment they will perish.
The [xref]a[/xref]Portion of Jacob is not like these; / For He is the One who formed everything, / And Israel is the tribe of His [xref]b[/xref]inheritance; / Jehovah of hosts is His name.
Gather up your bundle from the ground, / O inhabitant under siege.
For thus says Jehovah, / I will sling out / The inhabitants of the land / At this time, / And I will bring distress on them, / That they may find [i]it.[/i]
Woe is me because of my hurt! / My wound is grievous. / But I said, Truly this is [i]my[/i] affliction, / And I must bear it.
My tent is destroyed, and all my cords are broken; / My children have gone from me and they are not; / There is no one who will spread out my tent again / And set up my curtains.
For the shepherds are stupid / And have not sought Jehovah; / Therefore they have not prospered, / And all their flock is [xref]a[/xref]scattered.
The sound of a report! Here it comes, / Even a great commotion [note]1[/note]from the land of the north, / To make the cities of Judah / A desolation, a habitation of jackals.
verse.note: I.e., from Babylon.

verse.text: I know, O Jehovah, / That a man's way is not in himself; / It is not in the man who walks / To direct his step.
[xref]a[/xref]Correct me, O Jehovah, but in measure, / Not in Your anger lest You bring me to nothing.

[xref]a[/xref]Pour out Your wrath on the nations / Who do not [xref]b[/xref]know You / And upon the families / Who do not call upon Your name; / For they have devoured Jacob, yes, devoured him and brought him to an end, / And they have desolated his habitation.
The word that came to Jeremiah from Jehovah, saying,
Listen to the words of this covenant and speak them to the men of Judah and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
And you shall say to them, Thus says Jehovah the God of Israel, Cursed is the man who does not listen to the words of this [note]1[/note]covenant,
verse.note: The covenant of Jehovah with Israel, called the first covenant and also the old covenant ([link]Heb. 8:7[/link], [link]13[/link]), was the covenant of the law of the Ten Commandments ([link]Exo. 20:1-24:8[/link]). The law, which itself is holy, righteous, good, and spiritual ([link]Rom. 7:12[/link], [link]16[/link], [link]14a[/link]), became weak through man's flesh ([link]Rom. 8:3a[/link]). The law of the Ten Commandments was given to test man and expose man as to his genuine nature and condition ([link]Rom. 3:20b[/link]; [link]5:20a[/link]; [link]7:7b[/link]). Through their failure under the test of the law, Israel was to learn that they were unable to keep the law and that they had no righteousness by the law ([link]Rom. 8:3a[/link]; [link]9:31[/link]; [link]10:3[/link]). They were also to come to know that they needed Christ to be Jehovah as their righteousness ([link]23:6b[/link]; [link]33:16b[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]), and they needed to have the divine life with its law in the new covenant of God ([link]31:31-34[/link]; [link]Heb. 8:8-12[/link]; [link]10:16-17[/link]).

verse.text: Which I commanded your fathers in the day that I brought them out of the land of Egypt, from the iron [xref]a[/xref]furnace, saying, Listen to My voice and do the things according to all which I command you; and you will be My people and [xref]b[/xref]I will be your God,

That I may establish the [xref]a[/xref]oath which I swore to your fathers, to give them a land [xref]b[/xref]flowing with milk and honey, as it is this day. And I answered and said, [xref]c[/xref]Amen, Jehovah.
And Jehovah said to me, Proclaim all these words in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem, saying, Hear the words of this covenant and do them.
For I solemnly warned your fathers in the day that I brought them up from the land of Egypt, even to this day, [xref]a[/xref]rising up early and warning, saying, Listen to My voice.

But they did not listen or incline their ear, but all walked in the stubbornness of their evil heart; therefore I brought upon them all the words of this covenant, which I commanded [i]them[/i] to do, and they have not done [i]them.[/i]
And Jehovah said to me, A conspiracy has been found among the men of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

They have turned back to the iniquities of their forefathers, who refused to listen to My words, and they have gone after other gods to serve them. The house of Israel and the house of Judah have [note]1[/note]broken My [xref]a[/xref]covenant which I made with their fathers.
verse.note: Israel broke the covenant of the law by their idolatrous worship ([link]vv. 10b[/link], [link]13[/link], [link]15a[/link], [link]17b[/link]; [link]13:10b[/link], [link]27a[/link]) and also by their evil conduct ([link]vv. 8[/link], [link]10a[/link], [link]19[/link]; [link]12:4a[/link]). By these two things they completely annulled the law, making it of no effect to them. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: Therefore thus says Jehovah, I am about to bring [note]1[/note]evil upon them, from which they cannot escape; and they will cry to Me, but I will not listen to them.
verse.note: Although God's intention in giving Israel His law was to test and expose them, He still needed to punish them for the sake of His righteousness and holiness.

verse.text: Then the cities of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem will go and cry to the gods to whom they burn incense, but they will not save them at all in the time of their trouble.

For [xref]a[/xref]according to the number of your cities are your gods, O Judah, and according to the number of the streets of Jerusalem you have set up altars to [i]that[/i] shameful thing, altars to burn incense to Baal.
And as for you, do not [xref]a[/xref]pray for this people, nor lift up a ringing cry or a prayer for them; for I will not hear when they call to Me because of their trouble.
What has My [xref]a[/xref]beloved to do in My house, / Since she has committed lewdness with many / And the holy flesh has passed from you? / When you do evil, then you rejoice.
Jehovah called your name, / A flourishing [xref]a[/xref]olive tree, beautiful in fruit and form; / With the sound of a great tumult / He has set fire to it, / And its branches are broken.

And Jehovah of hosts, who [xref]a[/xref]planted you, has pronounced evil against you because of the evil of the house of Israel and of the house of Judah, which they have done for themselves, to provoke Me to anger by burning incense to Baal.
And Jehovah made it known to me, so I knew; then You showed me their deeds.

And I was like a gentle [xref]a[/xref]lamb led to the slaughter, and I did not know that they devised devices against me, [i]saying,[/i] Let us destroy the tree with its fruit, and let us cut him off from the land of the living that his name be remembered no longer.

[xref]a[/xref]But, O Jehovah of hosts, who judges righteously, / Who [xref]b[/xref]tests the inward parts and the heart, / Let me see Your [note]1[/note]vengeance on them, / For I have revealed my cause to You.
verse.note: Jeremiah's prayer for vengeance was contrary to the New Testament teaching, which tells us to love our enemies and pray for those who persecute us ([link]Matt. 5:44[/link]). Cf. note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 3[/link].

verse.text: Therefore thus says Jehovah concerning the men of Anathoth, who seek your life, saying, Do not prophesy in the name of Jehovah, that you may not die by our hand;
Therefore thus says Jehovah of hosts, I am about to punish them: The young men will die by the sword; their sons and their daughters will die by famine;
And they will have no remnant, because I will bring evil to the men of Anathoth in the year of their punishment.

You are righteous, O Jehovah, / When I plead [i]my[/i] cause with You; / Yet I will speak with You of [i]Your[/i] judgments: / [note]1[/note]Why does the way of the [xref]a[/xref]wicked prosper? / [i]Why[/i] are all those who deal treacherously at ease?
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 1[/link] and note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 73[/link].

verse.text: You have planted them; they have also taken root; / They go on and bring forth fruit. / You are near, in their mouth, / But far from their inward parts.
And You, O Jehovah, [xref]a[/xref]know me; You see me / And [xref]b[/xref]try my heart toward You. / Pull them out like sheep for the slaying, / And set them apart for the day of slaughter.

How long will the land mourn / And the grass of every field dry up? / Because of the wickedness of those who dwell in it, / Beasts and birds are swept away, / Because they said, He will not see our end.

If you have run with footmen and they have wearied you, / How then will you compete with horses? / [i]If[/i] you are secure in a land of peace, / How then will you do in the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]majesty of the Jordan?
verse.note: I.e., the dangerous thickets along the Jordan.

verse.text: For even your brothers and the house of your father, / Even they have dealt treacherously with you; / Even they have cried aloud after you. / Do not believe them, although they speak good things to you.
I have forsaken My house; / I have abandoned My inheritance; / I have given the beloved of My soul / Into the hand of her enemies.
My inheritance has become to Me / Like a lion in the forest; / She lifted up her voice against Me, / Therefore I hated her.
Is My inheritance a speckled bird of prey to Me? / Are the birds of prey against her all around? / Go, gather all the beasts of the field; / Bring them to devour.
Many shepherds have destroyed My [xref]a[/xref]vineyard; / They have trampled down My portion; / They have made My pleasant portion / A desolate wilderness.
They have made it a desolation; / Desolate, it mourns to Me; / The whole land has been desolated / Because no one lays it to heart.
Upon all the bare heights in the wilderness / Destroyers have come, For the sword of Jehovah devours / From one end of the land to the other end of the land; / No flesh has peace.
They have sown wheat, and they reap thorns; / They have worn themselves out, but they profit nothing; / Therefore be ashamed of your produce / Because of the burning anger of Jehovah.

Thus says Jehovah concerning all My evil neighbors, who have touched the inheritance which I caused My people Israel to inherit, I am about to pluck them up out of their land, and I will pluck up the house of Judah out from their midst.
And after I have plucked them up, I will [xref]a[/xref]return and have compassion on them and bring them again, each one to his inheritance and each one to his land.

And if they will diligently learn the ways of My people, to swear by My name, [i]saying,[/i] As Jehovah lives, even as they taught My people to swear by Baal, they will be built up in the midst of My people.
But if they do not listen, I will pluck up that nation, plucking [i]it[/i] up and destroying [i]it,[/i] declares Jehovah.
Thus said Jehovah to me, Go and buy yourself a linen girdle, and put it on your loins, but do not put it in water.
So I bought a girdle according to the word of Jehovah and put [i]it[/i] upon my loins.
And the word of Jehovah came to me a second time, saying,
Take the girdle which you bought, which is upon your loins, and rise up; go to the Euphrates, and hide it there in a cleft of the rock.
And I went and I hid it by the Euphrates, as Jehovah had commanded me.
And at the end of many days Jehovah said to me, Rise up; go to the Euphrates, and take from there the girdle which I commanded you to hide there.
And I went to the Euphrates and dug, and I took the girdle from the place where I had hidden it; and there the girdle was, spoiled and good for nothing.
And the word of Jehovah came to me, saying,
Thus says Jehovah, Even so I will destroy the pride of Judah and the great pride of Jerusalem.

This evil people, who refuse to hear My words, who walk in the stubbornness of their heart and go after other gods to serve them and to worship them, will be even like this girdle, which is good for nothing.

For as this girdle clings to the loins of a man, so I have caused all the house of Israel and all the house of Judah to cling to Me, declares Jehovah, that they might be to Me a people and a name and a praise and a glory; but they would not listen.

And you shall speak to them this word, Thus says Jehovah the God of Israel, Every wineskin will be filled with wine. And they will say to you, Do we not know very well that every wineskin will be filled with wine?

Then you shall say to them, Thus says Jehovah, I am about to fill all the inhabitants of this land and the kings who sit in David's place on his throne and the priests and the prophets and all the inhabitants of Jerusalem with drunkenness,
And I will dash them one against the other, both the fathers and the sons together, declares Jehovah; I will not spare or pity or have compassion so as not to destroy them.
Hear and give ear and do not be proud, / For Jehovah has spoken.

Give glory to Jehovah your God, / Before He brings darkness, / And before your feet stumble on the twilight mountains; / And you will look for light, / But He will turn it into a shadow of death / [i]And[/i] make [i]it[/i] deep darkness.

And if you will not hear it, / My soul will [note]1[/note]weep in secret places for [i]your[/i] pride; / And my eye will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]weep bitterly and shed tears, / Because the [xref]b[/xref]flock of Jehovah has been taken captive.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: Say to the king and to the queen mother, / Humble yourselves [i]and[/i] sit down, / For your beautiful crown / Has come down from your heads.
The cities of the south have been shut up, / And there is no one to open [i]them;[/i] / All Judah has been taken into exile, / Wholly taken into exile.
Lift up your eyes, / And see those who come from the [xref]a[/xref]north. / Where is the flock that was given to you, / Your beautiful sheep?

What will you say when He appoints over you as head / Those whom you yourself have trained to be your friends? / Will not [xref]a[/xref]pains take hold of you, / Like those of a [xref]b[/xref]woman in travail?

And if you say in your heart, / Why have these things happened to me? / [i]It is[/i] because of the greatness of your iniquity [i]that[/i] your skirts are uncovered, / [i]That[/i] your heels suffer violence.
Can the [note]1[/note]Cushite change his skin, / Or the leopard his spots? / [i]Then[/i] you also may be able to do good, / Who are [xref]a[/xref]accustomed to do evil.
verse.note: I.e., Ethiopian. Having forsaken God as the source, the fountain of living waters ([link]2:13[/link]), Israel became evil, having a heart that was deceitful above all things and incurable ([link]17:9[/link]) and having an unchangeable sinful nature, like the Cushite's skin and the leopard's spots, which cannot be changed. This exposes the true condition of fallen man.

verse.text: Therefore I will scatter them like chaff driven / By the wind of the wilderness.
This is your lot, / The portion measured out to you from Me, / Declares Jehovah, / Because you have forgotten Me / And have trusted in falsehood.
I will also strip your skirts off over your head, / And your shame will be seen.

Your adulteries and your neighings, / The lewdness of your fornication / Upon the hills, in the field, / Your detestable things — I have seen. / Woe to you, O Jerusalem! / How long a time will you still not be clean?
The word of Jehovah that came to Jeremiah concerning the [note]1[/note]drought:
verse.note: Jehovah's punishing Israel with drought ([link]3:3a[/link]) was a curse for Israel's breaking of Jehovah's covenant ([link]Deut. 11:17[/link]; [link]28:23[/link]). It was the ceasing of God's heavenly supply to the earth. Such a thing took place during the time of Elijah ([link]1 Kings 17:1[/link]), and it will happen again in the future ([link]Rev. 11:6a[/link]; [link]Zech. 14:17-18[/link]).

verse.text: Judah mourns, / And her gates languish; / In black they mourn on the ground, / And the cry of Jerusalem goes up.

And their nobles send their servants for water; / They come to cisterns, / And they find [xref]a[/xref]no water; / They return with their vessels empty; / They are ashamed and confounded / And cover their heads.
Because the ground is cracked, / For there has been no rain on the earth, / The farmers are ashamed; / They cover their heads.
For even the hind in the field gives birth and abandons [i]its young[/i] / Because there is no grass.
And the wild asses stand on the bare heights; / They pant after the wind like jackals; / Their eyes fail, / For there is no herbage.
Although our iniquities testify against us, / O Jehovah, act for Your [xref]a[/xref]name's sake, / For our apostasies have become many; / We have sinned against You.
O [xref]a[/xref]Hope of Israel, / Its Savior in a time of distress, / Why should You be like a sojourner in the land, / Like a traveler who turns aside to lodge for the night?

Why should You be like an astonished man, / Like a mighty man who is unable to save? / Yet You are in our [xref]a[/xref]midst, O Jehovah, / And we are called by Your [xref]b[/xref]name; / Do not leave us.

Thus says Jehovah to this people, Even so they have loved to wander; they have not restrained their feet. Therefore Jehovah has no delight in them; now He will [xref]a[/xref]remember their iniquity and punish their sins.
And Jehovah said to me, Do not [xref]a[/xref]pray for the welfare of this people.
When they fast, I will not listen to their cry; when they offer up a burnt offering and a meal offering, I will not accept them; but by sword and by famine and by pestilence I will consume them.
And I said, Ah, Lord Jehovah! Indeed, the prophets say to them, You will not see sword, nor will you have famine, for I will give you assured peace in this place.

And Jehovah said to me, The prophets prophesy [xref]a[/xref]falsehood in My name; I did not send them or command them or speak to them. They are prophesying to you a false vision and divination and a worthless thing and the deceit of their own heart.

Therefore thus says Jehovah concerning the prophets who prophesy in My name, although I did not send them, yet they say, A sword and famine will not be in this land: By sword and by famine those prophets will be consumed.

And the people to whom they prophesy will be cast out into the streets of Jerusalem because of the famine and the sword; and there will be no one to bury them — them, their wives, and their sons and their daughters — and I will pour out their [i]own[/i] wickedness on them.

And you shall speak this word to them, / Let [note]1[/note]my eyes run down with [xref]a[/xref]tears / Night and day, and let them not cease; / For the virgin daughter of my people is broken with great brokenness, / A very grievous wound.
verse.note: The prophet was one with the punishing God to sympathize with the people. See notes [link chapter="9"]1[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: If I go forth into the field — / Look, those slain by the sword; / And if I come into the city — / Look, those diseased with famine. / For both the prophet and the priest / Will go about in a land that they do not know.
