Have You utterly [xref]a[/xref]rejected Judah? / Or does Your soul loathe Zion? / Why have You stricken us / So that there is no healing for us? / [xref]b[/xref][i]We[/i] looked for peace, but no good [i]came;[/i] / And for a time of healing, but there was terror.
We acknowledge, O Jehovah, our wickedness, / The iniquity of our fathers, for we have [xref]a[/xref]sinned against You.
Do not hold us in contempt, for Your name's sake; / Do not dishonor Your throne of glory; / Remember [i]and[/i] do not break Your covenant with us.

Are there among the [xref]a[/xref]vanities of the nations any that can bring rain, / Or [i]in[/i] the heavens any that can give showers? / Are You not He, O Jehovah our God? / Therefore we wait for You, / For You have made all these things.

And Jehovah said to me, [xref]a[/xref]Even though [xref]b[/xref]Moses and [xref]c[/xref]Samuel were to stand before Me, My soul would not [i]turn[/i] toward this people. Send them out of My sight and let them go.

And when they say to you, Where shall we go? Then you shall say to them, Thus says Jehovah,[br/][xref]a[/xref]Those who are for death to death, / And those who are for the sword to the sword, / And those who are for famine to famine, / And those who are for captivity to captivity.
And I will visit them with four kinds [i]of punishment,[/i] declares Jehovah: the sword to slay, and the dogs to tear, and the birds of heaven and the beasts of the earth to devour and destroy.
And I will make them a horror among all the kingdoms of the earth, because of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Manasseh the son of Hezekiah, the king of Judah, for that which he did in Jerusalem.
verse.note: See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Kings 21[/link].

verse.text: For who will have pity on you, O Jerusalem, / And who will lament for you; / And who will turn aside to ask / After your welfare?

You have [xref]a[/xref]forsaken Me, / Declares Jehovah. / You keep going backward, / And I have stretched out My hand against you / And have destroyed you; / I have become [note]1[/note]weary of [xref]b[/xref]repenting.
verse.note: [link]Verses 5-9[/link] are a record of the punishing Jehovah's sighing for His punished people. Again and again God had determined to punish Israel, but He had repented. Now He told Jeremiah that He was weary of repenting and would repent no more. This shows how evil Israel had become and how patient God had been with them.

verse.text: And I have winnowed them with a winnowing fork / In the gates of the land; / I have bereaved [i]them[/i] of children / And destroyed My people; / They have [xref]a[/xref]not turned back from their ways.

Their widows have increased before Me / More than the sand of the seas; / I have brought to them, / Against the mother of the young men, / A spoiler at noon; / I have caused anguish and terror / To fall on her suddenly.

She who has borne seven languishes; / She has breathed out her life. / Her sun has gone down while it is still day; / She is put to shame and confounded. / And the rest of them I will give up to the sword / Before their enemies, / Declares Jehovah.

[note]1[/note]Woe is me, my mother, because you [xref]a[/xref]bore me, / A man of strife and a man of contention to the whole land. / I have not lent with interest, / Nor have they lent to me; / Yet everyone curses me.
verse.note: God was intending to judge the people of Israel, and He sent Jeremiah to tell them that He would use the Babylonians to punish them ([link]vv. 12-13[/link]). They responded by persecuting Jeremiah ([link]v. 15[/link]; [link]11:19[/link]; [link]18:18-23[/link]; [link]20:1-2[/link], [link]7-10[/link]), and this caused him to be disappointed. As Jeremiah complained, God came in to speak to him for his encouragement and strengthening ([link]v. 11[/link]). This indicates that God was always with Jeremiah. In His speaking to Jeremiah, God spoke not as the Divine Being, as the Mighty One, but almost as if He were a man, talking in a very human and personal way. According to the record of this book, as God dealt with His people, He often spoke to them in such a way (e.g., [link]2:1-3:5[/link]; [link]3:12-4:2[/link]; [link]16:10-18[/link]).

verse.text: Jehovah said, Surely I will set you free for [i]your[/i] good; / Indeed I will cause the enemy to make supplication to you / In a time of trouble and in a time of distress.
Can one break [note]1[/note]iron, / Iron from the north, or bronze?
verse.note: The word [i]iron[/i] here refers to the Babylonians. God was assuring Jeremiah that He would use the Babylonians to punish Israel.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Your wealth and your treasures / I will give as plunder without price, / And that for all your sins, / And within all your borders.
verse.note: The pronouns [i]your[/i] and [i]you[/i] in [link]vv. 13-14[/link], referring to both Israel and Jeremiah, indicate that God regarded Jeremiah the prophet as being one with Israel and that God considered the entire nation of Israel as one entity. Because Jeremiah was a part of this entity, when the wealth and treasures of Israel were given to their enemies, Jeremiah also became poor.

verse.text: I will cause your enemies to bring [i]it[/i] / Into a land you do not know; / For a fire is kindled in My anger, / Which will burn against you.

O Jehovah, You know; / Remember me and visit me, / And [note]1[/note]avenge me of my persecutors. / Do not let Your long-suffering [i]for them prevail and[/i] have me taken away; / Know that for Your sake I bear [xref]a[/xref]reproach.
verse.note: Cf. note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 3[/link].

verse.text: Your words were found and I [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ate them, / And Your [xref]b[/xref]word became to me / The gladness and joy of my heart, / For I am called by Your name, / O Jehovah, God of hosts.
verse.note: According to the entire revelation in the Holy Bible, God's words are good for us to eat, and we need to eat them ([link]Psa. 119:103[/link]; [link]Matt. 4:4[/link]; [link]Heb. 5:12-14[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:2-3[/link]). God's word is the divine supply as food to nourish us. Through the word as our food, God dispenses His riches into our inner being to nourish us that we may be constituted with His element. This is a crucial aspect of God's economy. When we eat God's words, His word becomes our heart's gladness and joy.

verse.text: I did not [xref]a[/xref]sit in the assembly of mockers, nor did I exult. / Because of Your hand I sat alone, / For You have filled me with indignation.
Why is my pain unceasing, / And my wound incurable, refusing to be healed? / Will You indeed be to me like a deceitful [i]brook?[/i] / [i]Like[/i] waters that fail?

Therefore thus says Jehovah, / If [note]1[/note]you [xref]a[/xref]return, I will restore you; / You will stand before Me; / And if you [note]2[/note]bring out the precious from the worthless, / You will be as My mouth; / They will turn to you, / But you will not turn to them.
verse.note: [link]Verses 19-21[/link] are Jehovah's response to Jeremiah's complaint ([link]vv. 10-18[/link]). In His response He gave Jeremiah a further commission. The pronoun [i]you[/i] here may be a further indication that God considered Jeremiah as being one with Israel (see [link]vv. 13-14[/link] and note [link]13[sup]1[/sup][/link]). Both Israel and Jeremiah, who was quite disappointed, needed to return to God in order to be restored by Him.
I.e., utter. Jehovah's word concerning uttering precious things may indicate that He regarded some of Jeremiah's speaking in the previous verses as worthless.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And I will make you to this people / A [note]1[/note]fortified wall of bronze; / And they will fight against you, / But they will not prevail against you; / For I am with you / To save you and deliver you, / Declares Jehovah.
verse.note: See note [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And I will deliver you from the hand of the wicked / And redeem you from the hand of those who terrorize.
The word of Jehovah also came to me, saying,
[note]1[/note]You shall not take a wife for yourself nor have sons or daughters in this place.
verse.note: [link]Verses 1-9[/link] are Jehovah's restrictions placed on Jeremiah for His further commission. God's restricting Jeremiah in the matters of marrying, mourning, and feasting indicates that if we would be a mouthpiece of God and speak for Him, we must be restricted. God's words to Jeremiah also indicate that those who are used by God to speak for Him will suffer.

verse.text: For thus says Jehovah concerning the sons and daughters who are born in this place and concerning their mothers who bear them and concerning their fathers who beget them in this land:

[xref]a[/xref]They will die grievous deaths and will not be mourned or buried; they will be as dung on the surface of the ground and will be consumed by sword and by famine, and their [xref]b[/xref]corpses will become food for the birds of the sky and the beasts of the earth.

For thus says Jehovah, Do not enter the house of mourning, and do not go to mourn, and do not lament for them, for I have taken away My peace from this people, declares Jehovah, My lovingkindness and compassions.
Both the great and the small will die in this land; they will not be buried, nor will they be mourned; and no one will cut himself or make himself bald for them.
Nor will they break [i]bread[/i] for them in mourning to comfort anyone for the dead or give them a cup of consolation to drink for his father or for his mother.
And you shall not enter the house of feasting to sit with them and eat and drink.

For thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, [xref]a[/xref]I will cause to cease from this place, before your eyes and in your days, the voice of gladness and the voice of joy, the voice of the bridegroom and the voice of the bride.

And when you tell this people all these words and they say to you, Why has Jehovah pronounced all this great evil against us? And what is our iniquity? And what is our sin which we have sinned against Jehovah our God?

Then you shall say to them, Because your fathers have [xref]a[/xref]forsaken Me, declares Jehovah, and they have gone after other gods to serve them and to worship them; but Me they have forsaken, and My law they have not kept.
And you have done more evil than your fathers; for indeed, you go about, each one after the stubbornness of his evil heart, without listening to Me.

And I will cast you far away from this land into a land which you have not known, [i]neither[/i] you nor your fathers; and there you will serve other gods day and night, for I will not show favor to you.
[xref]a[/xref]Therefore indeed, days are coming, declares Jehovah, when it will no longer be said, As Jehovah lives, who brought up the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt,

But, As Jehovah lives, who [note]1[/note]brought up the children of Israel out of the land of the north and out of all the lands where He had driven them; for I will bring them back to their own land, which I gave to their fathers.
verse.note: In answering the inquiry of the people concerning the reason for the great evil, the calamities, that had come upon them ([link]v. 10[/link]), Jehovah promised to bring them back to the land, telling them that He would even send "fishermen" to catch them and "hunters" to hunt for them in order to gather them and restore them ([link]vv. 15-16[/link]; see reference [link]31[sup]a[/sup] in Matt. 24[/link]).

verse.text: I am soon sending many fishermen, declares Jehovah, and they will catch them; and afterward I will send many hunters, and they will hunt for them from every mountain and from every hill and from the clefts of the rocks.
For My eyes are upon all their ways; they are not concealed from My face, neither is their iniquity hidden from My eyes.

But first I will recompense [xref]a[/xref]double for their iniquity and their sin, because they have profaned My land with the corpses of their detestable things, and their abominations have filled My inheritance.

O Jehovah, my strength and my stronghold, / My [xref]a[/xref]refuge in the day of distress; / To You the nations come / From the ends of the earth and say, / Surely our fathers inherited falsehood / [i]And[/i] vanity, in which there is no profit.
Shall a man make gods for himself, / Though they are [xref]a[/xref]no gods?
Therefore now, I am causing them to know; / At this time I will cause them to know / My hand and My might, / And they will know that My name is Jehovah.
The sin of Judah is written / With an [xref]a[/xref]iron pen; / With the point of an adamant it is engraved / On the tablet of their [xref]b[/xref]heart / And on the horns of your altars,
While their children remember / Their altars and their [note]1[/note]Asherahs / Beside flourishing trees / Upon high hills.
verse.note: Images of a female deity.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]O My mountain in the field, / Your wealth and all your treasures / I will give as plunder, / Your high places, because of sin, / Within all your borders.

And you [note]1[/note]yourself will let go of your inheritance, / Which I gave to you; / And I will cause you to serve your enemies / In a land which you do not know; / For you have kindled a fire in My anger, / Which will burn forever.
verse.note: The meaning of the Hebrew is uncertain.

verse.text: Thus says Jehovah, / Cursed is the man who trusts in man / And makes flesh his arm / And whose heart turns away from Jehovah.
And he will be like a shrub in the desert / And will not see when good comes; / But he will dwell in the parched places in the wilderness, / A land of salt and uninhabited.
Blessed is the man who [xref]a[/xref]trusts in Jehovah / And whose trust Jehovah is.

And he will be like a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]tree transplanted beside water, / Which sends out its roots by a stream, / And will not be afraid when heat comes; / For its leaves remain flourishing, / And it will not be anxious in the year of drought / And will not cease to bear fruit.
verse.note: According to God's economy, the one who trusts in God is like a tree planted by water, signifying God as the fountain of living waters ([link]2:13a[/link]). A tree grows beside a river by absorbing all the riches of the water. This is a picture of God's economy, which is carried out by His dispensing. In order to receive the divine dispensing, we as the trees must absorb God as the water (cf. [link]1 Cor. 3:6[/link]). The riches of the supplying God dispensed into us as the trees constitute us with God's divinity and cause us to grow into God's measure ([link]Col. 2:19[/link]). In this way we and God become one, having the same element, essence, constitution, and appearance ([link]Rev. 4:3[/link]; [link]21:11[/link]).

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]heart is deceitful above all things, / And it is incurable; / Who can know it?
verse.note: Even this word regarding the deceitful and incurable heart of man is related to God's economy with His dispensing. Although man's heart is corrupt and deceitful and its condition is incurable, even such a heart can be a tablet upon which God writes His law of life ([link]31:33[/link]; cf. [link]2 Cor. 3:3[/link]). This reveals that God has a way to impart Himself into man. Once He has come into man, God will spread from man's spirit into his heart. This is God's way, according to His economy, to deal with the heart of fallen man. See [link]Ezek. 36:26[/link] and note.

verse.text: I, Jehovah, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]search the heart / [i]And[/i] test the inward parts, / Even to give to each one according to his ways, / According to the fruit of his deeds.
verse.note: Lit., dig.

verse.text: [i]As[/i] a partridge broods over what she has not laid, / A man makes riches but not rightly; / In the midst of his days they will leave him, / And at his end he will be a fool.
A throne of glory set on high from the beginning / Is the place of our sanctuary.

[i]You are[/i] the [xref]a[/xref]hope of Israel, O Jehovah; / All who forsake You will be put to shame. / Those who turn away from Me will be written in the earth / Because they [note]1[/note]forsook Jehovah, / The [xref]b[/xref]fountain of living waters.
verse.note: See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]. [link]Jeremiah 2:13[/link]; [link]15:16[/link]; and [link]17:7-8[/link] (see notes on these verses) present basic points of the divine thought concerning the carrying out of God's economy by His dispensing. As God accomplishes His economy by dispensing Himself into us, He is our food, our water, and our fountain of living waters. How marvelous it is that in a portion of the Word concerned with God's chastisement of His sinful and evil people, such a full picture of God's economy accomplished by His dispensing is presented!

verse.text: Heal me, O Jehovah, and I will be healed; / Save me and I will be saved, / For You are my praise.
Indeed, they say to me, / [xref]a[/xref]Where is the word of Jehovah? / Let it come now!
But as for me, I have not hurried away from being a shepherd after You, / And I have not desired a day of disaster. / You know that what came out of my lips / Was before Your face.
Do not become a terror to me; / You are my [xref]a[/xref]refuge in an evil day.

Let those who persecute me be put to shame, but as for me, do not let me be / put to shame; / Let them be dismayed, but do not let me be dismayed. / Bring upon them an evil day, / And break them with a double destruction.
Thus said Jehovah to me, Go and stand in the gate of the sons of the people, through which the kings of Judah come in and through which they go out, and in all the gates of Jerusalem,
And say to them, Hear the word of Jehovah, O kings of Judah and all Judah and all the inhabitants of Jerusalem who enter through these gates:
Thus says Jehovah, Take heed to your souls and bear no burden on the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sabbath day, nor bring [i]anything[/i] through the gates of Jerusalem.
verse.note: See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 20[/link].

verse.text: And do not bring out any burden from your houses on the Sabbath day, nor do any work; but sanctify the Sabbath day, as I commanded your fathers.
But they did not listen or incline their ear; rather they stiffened their neck that they might not hear or receive correction.
But if indeed you listen to Me, declares Jehovah, and bring no burden through the gates of this city on the Sabbath day, but sanctify the Sabbath day and do not do any work on it,

[xref]a[/xref]Then kings and princes who sit on the throne of David, riding on chariots and on horses, they and their princes, the men of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, will come through the gates of this city; and this city will be inhabited forever.

And they will come from the cities of Judah and the places surrounding Jerusalem and from the land of Benjamin and from the lowland and from the hill country and from the [note]1[/note]Negev, bringing burnt offerings and sacrifices and meal offerings and frankincense and bringing thanksgiving to the house of Jehovah.
verse.note: I.e., the dry southern desert of Canaan; the term is generally used to refer to the south.

verse.text: But if you do not listen to Me to sanctify the Sabbath day and not to bear a burden when coming in through the gates of Jerusalem on the Sabbath day, then I will kindle a fire in its gates, and it will devour the palaces of Jerusalem and will not be extinguished.
The word which came to Jeremiah from Jehovah, saying,
Arise and go down to the [note]1[/note]potter's house, and there I will let you hear My words.
verse.note: Jeremiah's word to Jehovah in [link]15:10-17:27[/link] indicates that there was something within Jeremiah that was different from God's thought regarding Israel. It might have been that the feeling within Jeremiah was that God's judgment upon Israel was too severe. After Jeremiah's complaining ([link]15:10[/link]), God came in to speak with Jeremiah, indicating to him that He was determined to use the Babylonians as iron to judge and punish Israel ([link]15:12[/link]). Following Jeremiah's experience in arguing with God, he wrote a section of his prophecy concerning Jehovah as the sovereign Potter, who has absolute right over Israel as His pottery ([link]vv. 1-10[/link]; cf. [link]Rom. 9:20-23[/link]). Jehovah as the sovereign Potter is able to work with the house of Israel, as the clay in His hand, in changeable ways according to Israel's condition ([link]vv. 6-10[/link]). This corrected Jeremiah's concept.

verse.text: So I went down to the potter's house, and he was there doing work at his wheel.
But the vessel that he was making of clay was spoiled in the potter's hand; so he reworked it into another vessel, as it seemed good for the potter to make.
And the word of Jehovah came to me, saying,
Am I not able to do with you, O house of Israel, as this potter does? declares Jehovah. Indeed, as the clay is in the hand of the [xref]a[/xref]potter, so you are in My hand, O house of Israel.
At the moment that I speak about a nation or about a kingdom, to pluck [i]it[/i] up or to break [i]it[/i] down or to destroy [i]it,[/i]
And if that nation concerning which I have spoken [xref]a[/xref]turns from its evil, I will [xref]b[/xref]repent of the evil that I intended to do to it.
And at the moment that I speak about a nation or a kingdom, to build [i]it[/i] up or to plant [i]it,[/i]
And if it does evil in My sight by not listening to My voice, then I will repent of the good with which I said I would benefit it.

[note]1[/note]And now speak to the men of Judah and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem, saying, Thus says Jehovah, Look, I am forming evil against you and devising a plan against you. [xref]a[/xref]Return now, each one of you from his evil way, and amend your ways and your deeds.
verse.note: Jehovah's further speaking in [link]vv. 11-23[/link] concerning the evil condition of Israel was His further vindication of Himself to Jeremiah. Although He had the full right to do with Israel whatever He wanted, He would not punish Israel in a way that was unfitting. Because of Israel's evil condition, Israel deserved to be punished.

verse.text: But they say, It is hopeless! For we will walk after our own devices and everyone will do [i]according to[/i] the stubbornness of his evil heart.
Therefore thus says Jehovah, / Ask now among the nations, / Who has heard such things? / The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]virgin of Israel / Has done a very horrible thing.
verse.note: Although Israel had been a virgin betrothed to Jehovah, she forsook Him, the reality, as her Fiancé and turned to idols, which are vanity (cf. [link]2 Cor. 11:2-3[/link]).

verse.text: Does the snow of Lebanon / Leave the rock of the field? / Or will the cold flowing waters / Coming from afar be dried up?

But My people have [xref]a[/xref]forgotten Me; / They burn incense to vanity,[br/]And they have been stumbled in their ways / [i]From[/i] the [note]1[/note]ancient paths / To walk on [note]1[/note]bypaths, / On a way which is not cast up,
verse.note: The ancient paths were the right paths, which their forefathers had taken. To take the bypaths is to go downward; to take the ancient paths, a way that is cast up, is to go upward.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]To make their land an astonishment, / A thing to be hissed at forever. / Everyone who passes by will be astonished / And shake his head.
Like the east wind I will scatter them / Before the enemy; / I will show them [i]My[/i] [xref]a[/xref]back and not [i]My[/i] face / In the day of their calamity.

Then they said, Come, let us [xref]a[/xref]devise plots against Jeremiah; for the law will not perish from the priest or counsel from the wise man or a word from the prophet. Come, let us smite him with the tongue, and let us not give heed to any of his words.
Give heed to me, O Jehovah, / And listen to the voice of those who contend with me.
Shall evil be recompensed with good? / For they have dug a pit for my life. / Remember how I stood before You / To speak good for their sake, / To turn away Your wrath from them.

Therefore [note]1[/note]deliver up their children to famine, / And give them over to the power of the sword; / And let their wives become / Bereaved of child and be widows; / And let their men be slaughtered to death, / Their young men struck by the sword in battle.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].

verse.text: Let a cry be heard from their houses / When You suddenly bring upon them a troop; / For they have dug a pit to capture me / And have hidden snares for my feet.

Yet You, O Jehovah, know / All their counsel against me for my death. / Do not be propitious to their iniquity, / And do not blot out their sin from before You; / But let them be overthrown before You; / Deal with them in the time of Your anger.
Thus says Jehovah, Go and buy a potter's earthenware jar, and [i]take[/i] some of the elders of the people and some of the elders of the priests;
And go out to the valley of the son of Hinnom, which is at the entrance of the Potsherd Gate, and proclaim there the words which I will speak to you,

And say, Hear the word of Jehovah, O kings of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem, Thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, I am about to bring evil upon this place, at which the ears of everyone who hears of it will tingle;

Because they have forsaken Me and have estranged this place [i]from Me[/i] and have burned incense in it to other gods, which neither they nor their fathers nor the kings of Judah knew, and they have filled this place with the blood of the innocent,

[xref]a[/xref]And they have built the high places of [xref]b[/xref]Baal to burn their children in the fire as burnt offerings to Baal, which I did not command or speak, nor did it come up in My heart.
Therefore indeed, days are coming, declares Jehovah, when this place will no longer be called [note]1[/note]Topheth, or the valley of the son of [note]1[/note]Hinnom, but the valley of slaughter.
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]8[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

verse.text: And I will make void the counsel of Judah and Jerusalem in this place, and I will cause them to fall by the sword before their enemies and by the hand of those who seek their life, and I will give their [xref]a[/xref]corpses to the birds of heaven and to the beasts of the earth for food.
And I will make this city an [xref]a[/xref]astonishment and a hissing; everyone who passes by it will be astonished and hiss at all its wounds.

And I will make them eat the flesh of their [xref]a[/xref]sons and the flesh of their daughters, and each one will eat his neighbor's flesh in the siege and in the distress with which their enemies and those who seek their life distress them.
And you shall break the jar in the sight of the men who go with you.

And you shall say to them, Thus says Jehovah of hosts, So I will break this people and this city in the same way as one breaks the potter's [xref]a[/xref]vessel so that it cannot be repaired any more, and they will bury in Topheth because there will be no [i]other[/i] place to bury.
Thus I will deal with this place, declares Jehovah, and with its inhabitants, so as to make this city like Topheth.

And the houses of Jerusalem and the houses of the kings of Judah will be like the place Topheth, defiled because of all the houses upon whose roofs they have burnt [xref]a[/xref]incense to all the host of heaven and poured out drink offerings to other gods.
Then Jeremiah came from Topheth, where Jehovah had sent him to prophesy, and stood in the court of the house of Jehovah and said to all the people,

Thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, I am about to bring to this city and upon all its cities all the evil that I have spoken against it because they have stiffened their [xref]a[/xref]neck so as not to hear My words.
Now Pashhur the son of Immer, the priest, who was chief officer in the house of Jehovah, heard Jeremiah prophesying these things.
And Pashhur struck Jeremiah the prophet and put him in the [xref]a[/xref]stocks that were at the upper gate of Benjamin, which was by the house of Jehovah.
And on the next day, when Pashhur released Jeremiah from the stocks, Jeremiah said to him, Jehovah no longer calls your name Pashhur, but [note]1[/note]Magor-missabib.
verse.note: Meaning [i]terror on every side[/i] (cf. [link]v. 10[/link]).

verse.text: For thus says Jehovah, I will make you a terror to yourself and to all your friends, and they will fall by the sword of their enemies while your eyes look on; and I will give all Judah into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he will exile them to [xref]a[/xref]Babylon and strike them with the sword.

I will also give all the wealth of this city and all its gains and all its precious things; indeed all the treasures of the kings of Judah I will give into the hand of their enemies, who will plunder them and capture them and bring them to Babylon.
And you, Pashhur, and all who dwell in your house will go into captivity and you will go to Babylon and die there and be buried there, you and all your friends to whom you prophesied falsely.
You have enticed me, O Jehovah, and I let myself be enticed; / You have laid hold of me and have prevailed. / I have become a [xref]a[/xref]laughingstock all day long; / Everyone mocks me.
For whenever I speak, I cry out; / I proclaim violence and destruction; / For the word of Jehovah has become to me / A reproach and a derision all day long.

But if I say, I will not mention Him / Or speak any more in His name, / Then it is in my heart like a [xref]a[/xref]burning fire, / Shut up in my bones, / And I am weary of holding it in, / Nor can I.

[xref]a[/xref]For I hear the slander of many, / Terror on every side: / Denounce; yes, let us denounce him. / Every familiar [xref]b[/xref]friend / Is watching for my stumbling: / Perhaps he will be deceived so we can prevail against him / And take our revenge on him.

But Jehovah is with me like a mighty one who terrifies; / Therefore my persecutors will stumble and not prevail; / They will be greatly ashamed, for they have not prospered, / With an eternal humiliation that will not be forgotten.
[xref]a[/xref]But, O Jehovah of hosts, who tries the righteous, / Who sees the inward parts and the heart, / Let me see Your vengeance on them, / For I have revealed my cause to You.
Sing to Jehovah; / Praise Jehovah; / For He has delivered the soul of the poor / From the hand of the evildoers.
[xref]a[/xref]Cursed be the day / On which I was born; / Let not the day be blessed / On which my mother bore me.
Cursed be the man who brought good news / To my father, saying, / A male child has been born to you, / Causing him much joy.
And let that man be like the cities / Which Jehovah [xref]a[/xref]overthrew and did not repent, / And let him hear the cry in the morning / And the alarm in the noontime;
Because he did not put me to death at the womb, / That my mother might be my grave, / And her womb always pregnant.
Why is this? Did I come out from the womb / To see trouble and sorrow, / That my days may be spent in shame?
The word which came to Jeremiah from Jehovah when King [xref]a[/xref]Zedekiah sent to him Pashhur the son of Malchiah and Zephaniah the son of Maaseiah the priest, saying,

Inquire for us of Jehovah, for [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon is making war against us. Perhaps Jehovah will deal with us according to all His wonderful deeds, so that he goes up from us.
verse.note: An alternate spelling of [i]Nebuchadnezzar[/i] in Hebrew, closer to the actual pronunciation of this king's name in his own language, Babylonian.

verse.text: Then Jeremiah said to them, Thus you will say to Zedekiah,

Thus says Jehovah the God of Israel, I am about to turn back the weapons of war which are in your hand and with which you are fighting against the king of Babylon and against the Chaldeans, who are besieging you outside the walls; and I will gather them together into the midst of this city.
I Myself will [xref]a[/xref]fight against you with an outstretched hand and with a strong arm and in anger and wrath and great indignation.
And I will strike the inhabitants of this city, both man and beast; they will die of a great pestilence.

And afterward, declares Jehovah, I will [xref]a[/xref]deliver Zedekiah the king of Judah and his servants and the people who remain in this city after the pestilence and after the sword and after the famine into the hand of Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon and into the hand of their enemies and into the hand of those who seek their life, and he will strike them with the edge of the sword and will not pity them or spare [i]them[/i] or have compassion [i]on them.[/i]
And to this people you shall say, Thus says Jehovah, I am setting [xref]a[/xref]before you the [xref]b[/xref]way of life and the way of death.

[xref]a[/xref]He who remains in this city will die by sword and by famine and by pestilence, but he who goes out and surrenders to the Chaldeans who are besieging you will live and have his own life as spoil.
For I have set My face against this city for evil and not for good, declares Jehovah; it will be given into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he will burn it with fire.
And to the house of the king of Judah [i]say,[/i] Hear the word of Jehovah,

O house of David, thus says Jehovah: / Execute judgment every morning, / And deliver him who has been robbed from the hand of the oppressor, / Lest My wrath go forth like fire / And burn, and there be no one to extinguish it, / Because of the evil of your deeds.
Indeed, I am against you, O inhabitant of the valley, / O rock of the plateau, declares Jehovah, / Those who say, Who will come down against us, / And who will enter into our habitations?
But I will punish you according to the fruit of your deeds, / Declares Jehovah, / And I will kindle a [xref]a[/xref]fire in her forest, / And it will devour all that is around her.
Thus says Jehovah, Go down to the house of the king of Judah, and speak this word there,
And say, Hear the word of Jehovah, O king of Judah, who sits on the throne of David, you and your servants and your people, who enter through these gates:

Thus says Jehovah, Execute judgment and righteousness, and deliver him who has been robbed from the hand of the oppressor, and do no wrong, do no violence, to the sojourner, the orphan, or the widow; nor shed innocent blood in this place.

[xref]a[/xref]For if you indeed do this thing, then kings sitting in David's place on his throne, riding in chariots and on horses — [note]1[/note]the king and his servants and his people will come through the gates of this house;
verse.note: Lit., he.

verse.text: But if you do not listen to these things, I swear by Myself, declares Jehovah, that this house will become a [xref]a[/xref]ruin.
For thus says Jehovah concerning the house of the king of Judah,[br/]You are Gilead to Me, / The summit of Lebanon; / Yet I will surely make you a wilderness, / Cities that are not inhabited.
And I will set apart [xref]a[/xref]destroyers against you, / Each with his weapons; / And they will cut down your choice cedars / And cast them into the fire.
[xref]a[/xref]And many nations will pass by this city, and they will say each one to his neighbor, Why has Jehovah done this to this great city?
And they will say, [i]It is[/i] because they forsook the covenant of Jehovah their God and bowed down to other gods and served them.
Do not weep for the one who died, nor lament for him; / [i]But[/i] weep bitterly for the one who goes away, / For he will no longer return and see / The land of his birth.

For thus says Jehovah concerning [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Shallum the son of Josiah, the king of Judah, who became king in the place of Josiah his father, who went away from this place: He will not return there any more;
verse.note: I.e., Jehoahaz.

verse.text: But in the place where they have exiled him he will [xref]a[/xref]die and never see this land again.

Woe to him who builds his house by unrighteousness / And his upper rooms by injustice, / Who uses his neighbor's service without [xref]a[/xref]wages / And does not give him [i]recompense for[/i] his work,
Who says, I will build myself a large house / With spacious upper chambers, / And cuts out for it windows; and it is paneled with cedar / And painted with vermilion.
Are you a king because you / Excel in cedar? / Did not your father eat and drink, / And execute judgment and righteousness? Thus it was well with him.
He judged the cause of the poor and needy; thus it was well. / Is not this to know Me? / Declares Jehovah.
But you have eyes and a heart / Only for your unjust gain / And for shedding innocent blood / And for oppression and doing violence.

Therefore thus says Jehovah concerning [xref]a[/xref]Jehoiakim the son of Josiah, the king of Judah,[br/]They will not wail for him, [i]saying,[/i] / Alas, my brother! or, Alas, sister! / They will not wail for him, [i]saying,[/i] / Alas, lord! or, Alas, his majesty!
He will be buried with the burial of a donkey — / Dragged and cast out / Beyond the gates of Jerusalem.
Go up to Lebanon and cry out; / And lift up your voice in Bashan, / And cry out from Abarim, / For all your lovers have been shattered.
I spoke to you in your prosperity; / [i]But[/i] you said, I will not listen. / This has been your way from your youth, / That you have not listened to My voice.
The wind will shepherd all your shepherds, / And your lovers will go into captivity; / Then you will be ashamed and confounded / Because of all your wickedness.
O inhabitant of Lebanon, / Nested among the cedars, / How you will be pitied when pains come to you, / Anguish like that of a woman giving birth.
As I live, declares Jehovah, Even though [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Coniah the son of Jehoiakim, the king of Judah, were a [xref]b[/xref]signet ring on My right hand, yet I would tear you off,
verse.note: Also called Jeconiah in [link]24:1[/link]; [link]28:4[/link]; [link]29:2[/link] and Jehoiachin in [link]52:31[/link].

verse.text: And I would [xref]a[/xref]give you into the hand of those who seek your life and into the hand of those whom you fear, even into the hand of Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon, and into the hand of the Chaldeans.
I will [xref]a[/xref]cast you and your mother who bore you far away into another land where you were not born, and there you will die.
But to the land to which they desire to return, they will not return.
Is this man [xref]a[/xref]Coniah a despised, shattered container? / Or is he a vessel no one delights in? / Why are he and his seed thrown away / And cast into a land which they do not know?
O land, land, land, / Hear the word of Jehovah:

Thus says Jehovah, / Write down this man as childless, / A man who will not prosper in his days; / For none of his [note]1[/note]seed will prosper / By sitting on the throne of David / Or by ruling again in Judah.
verse.note: See note [link]11[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link].

verse.text: Woe to the [xref]a[/xref]shepherds who destroy and scatter the sheep of My pasture, declares Jehovah.

Therefore thus says Jehovah the God of Israel concerning the shepherds who shepherd My people, You have scattered My flock and driven them away and have not visited them; I will visit upon you the evil of your deeds, declares Jehovah.

Then I will [xref]a[/xref]gather the [xref]b[/xref]remnant of My flock out of all the lands where I have driven them, and I will bring them back to their pasture; and they will be fruitful and multiply.
And I will raise up shepherds over them who will shepherd them, and they will no longer fear or be dismayed, nor will any be missing, declares Jehovah.

[xref]a[/xref]Indeed, days are coming, / Declares Jehovah, / When I will raise up to David a righteous [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Shoot; / And He will reign as [note]2[/note]King and act prudently / And will execute justice and righteousness in the land.
verse.note: This is Christ incarnated as a man in the flesh to be the descendant of David ([link]Matt. 1:1[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:3[/link]). [i]Shoot[/i] here indicates Christ's humanity; it also implies life. When Christ was born, a new, fresh sprout came forth from the stump of David (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Isa. 11[/link]). This was the beginning of the fulfillment of Jehovah's promise concerning the raising up of Christ as the Shoot of David.

Christ's reigning as King implies His resurrection and ascension. Having passed through resurrection and having entered into ascension, Christ is now the King of kings, the Lord of Lords, and the Ruler of the kings of the earth ([link]Rev. 17:14[/link]; [link]19:16[/link]; [link]1:5[/link]). The word here concerning Christ will be fulfilled in the millennium ([link]Zech. 14:9[/link]; [link]Rev. 11:15[/link]; [link]20:6[/link]). See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: In His days Judah will be saved, / And Israel will dwell securely; / And this is His name by which He will be called, / [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Jehovah [note]2[/note]our [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]righteousness.
verse.note: [i]Jehovah our righteousness[/i] refers to Christ in His divinity, and [i]a righteous Shoot[/i] ([link]v. 5[/link]), to Christ in His humanity. The name here indicates that Christ, as a descendant of David, is not merely a man but is also the very Jehovah who created the heavens and the earth, selected Abraham, established the race of Israel, and was the Lord of David, the One whom he called Lord ([link]Matt. 22:42-45[/link]; cf. [link]Rev. 5:5[/link]; [link]22:16[/link]). Christ came as a Shoot who is Jehovah Himself to be the righteousness of God's chosen people.

[i]Our[/i] here indicates that Christ becomes one with us to be our righteousness ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]). Christ is made our righteousness based on His redemption. As the righteous Shoot ([link]v. 5[/link]), Christ came in the flesh as the descendant of David to die on the cross and shed His blood in order to wash away our sins and accomplish redemption ([link]Eph. 1:7[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:22[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:18-19[/link]). With His redemption as the basis, we can believe into Him to receive God's forgiveness ([link]Acts 10:43[/link]), and God can justify us ([link]Rom. 3:24[/link], [link]26[/link]), make Christ our righteousness, and clothe us with the robe of righteousness ([link]Isa. 61:10[/link]). This opens the way for Christ as the embodiment of the Triune God ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]) to enter into us as our life ([link]Col. 3:4a[/link]), our inner law of life ([link]31:33[/link]), and our everything, to dispense Himself into our entire being for the accomplishing of God's eternal economy.

Israel's evil and wickedness prepared the way for Christ to come in to be their righteousness. Although Israel forsook God for idols ([link]2:13[/link]) and became incurably evil ([link]13:23[/link]; [link]17:9[/link]), because of His compassions, lovingkindness, faithfulness, and eternal love ([link]31:3[/link]; [link]Lam. 3:22-23[/link]), God would never give up His elect yet distracted people. While He was condemning, punishing, and chastising Israel, He intended to be incarnated as a Shoot unto David so that He could be His people's righteousness. Based on Christ's coming as Jehovah to be their righteousness, the evil race of Israel can be restored. Eventually, Israel will manifest Christ, who is their righteousness, as their centrality (their being) and their universality (their expression). This manifestation will consummate in the New Jerusalem ([link]Rev. 21:12[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Therefore indeed, days are coming, declares Jehovah, when they will no longer say, As Jehovah lives, who brought up the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt;

But, As Jehovah lives, who brought up and led back the seed of the house of Israel out of the land of the north and out of [xref]a[/xref]all the lands where I had driven them, that they might dwell in their own land.

Concerning the prophets:[br/]My heart is broken within me; / All my bones fail. / I have become like a man who is drunk, / Even like a mighty man who is overcome by wine, / Because of Jehovah / And because of the words of His holiness.
For the land is full of adulterers; / For the land mourns because of the curse. / The pastures of the wilderness are dried up, / And the course they run is evil, / And their might is not right.
For both the prophet and the priest are profane; / Even in My house I have found their wickedness, / Declares Jehovah.

Therefore their way will become like slippery paths for them; / In the darkness they will be driven and will fall in it; / For I will bring evil on them / In the year of their punishment, declares Jehovah.
And in the prophets of Samaria / I have seen an offensive thing: / They prophesied by Baal / And led My people Israel astray.

And yet in the prophets of Jerusalem / I have seen a horrible thing: / The committing of adultery and walking in falsehood; / And they strengthen the hands of evildoers, / So that none turn / From their wickedness. / All of them have become to Me like [xref]a[/xref]Sodom / And her inhabitants like Gomorrah.

[xref]a[/xref]Therefore thus says Jehovah of hosts concerning the prophets: / I will feed them with [xref]b[/xref]wormwood / And give them poisonous water to drink, / For profaneness has gone forth / From the prophets of Jerusalem into all the land.

Thus says Jehovah of hosts, / Do not listen to the words of the prophets who are prophesying to you; / They are leading you to [note]1[/note]vanity; / They speak a vision of their own heart, / Not out of the mouth of Jehovah.
verse.note: I.e., idols.

verse.text: They say continually to those who despise Me, / Jehovah has spoken, You will have peace; / And to everyone who walks in the stubbornness of his own heart, / They say, Evil will not come upon you.
For who has stood in the [note]1[/note]council of Jehovah, / That he should perceive and hear His word? / Who has given heed to His word and listened?
verse.note: Or, counsel. So also in [link]v. 22[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Look, the storm wind of Jehovah! Wrath has gone forth, / Even a whirling tempest; / It will whirl down on the head of the wicked.
The anger of Jehovah will not turn back / Until He has executed and until He has accomplished / The purposes of His heart; / In the last days / You will understand it clearly.
I did not send the prophets, / But they ran forth; / I did not speak to them, / Yet they prophesied.
But if they had stood in My council / And had caused My people to hear My words, / They would have turned them from their evil way / And from the evil of their deeds.
Am I a God who is near, declares Jehovah, / And not a God who is far off?
Can a man hide [xref]a[/xref]himself in secret places, / So that I will not see him? declares Jehovah. / Do I not fill the heavens and the earth? / Declares Jehovah.
I have heard what the prophets say, who prophesy falsehood in My name, saying, I have dreamed; I have dreamed.
How long will [i]this[/i] be in the heart of the prophets who prophesy falsehood and who are prophets of the deceit of their own heart,
Who think to cause My people to forget My name with their dreams which they tell, each one to his neighbor, even as their fathers forgot My name because of Baal?
The prophet who has a dream, let him tell the dream; and he with whom is My word, let him speak My word faithfully. What is the [note]1[/note]straw to the [note]1[/note]grain? declares Jehovah.
verse.note: The word of God that came forth from Jeremiah was grain, food for nourishment that contains the divine essence to be dispensed into God's people; but the word of the false prophets was straw, chaff.

verse.text: Is not My word thus — like [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fire, declares Jehovah, and like a [note]1[/note]hammer that breaks the rock in pieces?
verse.note: On the positive side, the word of God, as a grain of wheat ([link]v. 28[/link]), dispenses God as life into us to nourish us. On the negative side, the word as fire burns us and many of the things in which we have confidence, and the word as a hammer breaks down our self, our natural life, our flesh, our lusts, and our concepts.

verse.text: Therefore indeed, I am against the prophets, declares Jehovah, who [note]1[/note]steal My words, each one from his neighbor.
verse.note: Jeremiah was a genuine prophet who received words from God. Although there were other genuine prophets (cf. [link]25:4[/link]), most of the prophets in Judah were false. These false prophets did not have a way to receive Jehovah's word, so they listened to those who spoke for God and then stole the words of Jehovah spoken by them. They pretended that they themselves had received this revelation from God and that the words they were speaking were their own.

verse.text: Indeed, I am against the prophets, declares Jehovah, who use their tongues and declare, He has declared.

Indeed, I am against those who prophesy false dreams, declares Jehovah, and who tell them and lead My people astray by their lies and by their recklessness, although I did not send them or command them; neither do they profit this people at all, declares Jehovah.
And when this people or the prophet or priest asks you, saying, What is the burden of Jehovah? then you shall say to them, What burden? I will even cast you off, declares Jehovah.
And as for the prophet and the priest and the people who say, The burden of Jehovah, I will punish that man and his household.
Thus you shall say every one to his neighbor and every one to his brother, What has Jehovah answered? or, What has Jehovah spoken?
And you shall mention no more the burden of Jehovah, for every man's word will be his [i]own[/i] burden; for you have perverted the words of the living God, Jehovah of hosts, our God.
Thus you shall say to the prophet, What has Jehovah answered you? or, What has Jehovah spoken?
But if you say, The burden of Jehovah, therefore thus says Jehovah, Because you have said this word, The burden of Jehovah, and I have sent to you, saying, You shall not say, The burden of Jehovah,
Therefore, I will utterly forget you and cast away from My presence you and the city which I gave to you and to your fathers.
And I will bring upon you eternal reproach and eternal humiliation, which will not be forgotten.

Jehovah showed me, and there were two baskets of [note]1[/note]figs placed before the temple of Jehovah, after [xref]a[/xref]Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon had exiled Jeconiah the son of Jehoiakim, the king of Judah, and the princes of Judah and the craftsmen and the smiths from Jerusalem and had brought them to Babylon.
verse.note: The fig tree is a symbol of the nation of Israel ([link]Joel 1:7[/link]). See [link]Matt. 21:18-22[/link] and notes.

verse.text: One basket had very good [xref]a[/xref]figs, like first ripe figs, but the other basket had very bad figs, which could not be eaten because of [i]their[/i] rottenness.
And Jehovah said to me, What do you see, Jeremiah? And I said, Figs. The good figs are very good; the bad [i]figs[/i] are very bad, which cannot be eaten because of [i]their[/i] rottenness.
Then the word of Jehovah came to me, saying,
Thus says Jehovah the God of Israel, Like these good figs, so I will regard those who are exiled of Judah, whom I have sent from this place to the land of the Chaldeans, for good.
And I will set My eyes upon them for good and will [xref]a[/xref]bring them back to this land and [xref]b[/xref]build them up and not tear them down, and I will plant them and not uproot them.

And I will give them a [xref]a[/xref]heart to know Me, that I am Jehovah; and they will be [xref]b[/xref]My people, and [xref]c[/xref]I will be their God; for they will return to Me with their whole heart.

And like the bad [xref]a[/xref]figs that cannot be eaten because of [i]their[/i] rottenness, thus says Jehovah, so I will make Zedekiah, the king of Judah, and his princes and the remnant of Jerusalem who remain in this land and [note]1[/note]those who dwell in the land of Egypt —
verse.note: Those dwelling in Egypt were those who had escaped from the Holy Land to Egypt for their security.

verse.text: I will even make them a terror to all the kingdoms of the earth for evil, to be a reproach and a [note]1[/note]proverb and a [note]1[/note]byword and a curse in all the places where I will drive them.
verse.note: Here [i]proverb[/i] signifies a formal expression of derision, and [i]byword[/i] indicates mocking.

verse.text: And I will send [xref]a[/xref]sword and famine and pestilence upon them until they are consumed from the land which I gave to them and to their fathers.

The word that came to Jeremiah concerning all the people of Judah in the [xref]a[/xref]fourth year of Jehoiakim the son of Josiah, the king of Judah (that is, the first year of [note]1[/note]Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon),
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 21[/link]. Shortly after Nebuchadnezzar came into power as king of Babylon, he attacked Judah, carried away some of the vessels in the temple, and captured a number of the people ([link]2 Chron. 36:6-7[/link]; [link]Dan. 1:1-6[/link]). In his prophecy, Jeremiah told the people of the evils, the calamities, that were coming upon them, and he advised them to repent and return to God.

verse.text: Which Jeremiah the prophet spoke to all the people of Judah and to all the inhabitants of Jerusalem, saying,

From the thirteenth year of Josiah the son of Amon, the king of Judah, even unto this day, these twenty-three years, the word of Jehovah came to me, and I spoke to you, [xref]a[/xref]rising up early and speaking, but you have not listened.
And Jehovah [xref]a[/xref]sent to you all His servants the prophets, rising up early and sending [i]them,[/i] but you have not listened or inclined your ear to hear,
Saying, Turn now every one from his evil way and from the evil of your deeds, and dwell upon the land which Jehovah has given you and your fathers from eternity to eternity;
And do not go after other gods to serve them and worship them; and do not provoke Me to anger with the work of your hands, and I will do you no harm.
Yet you have not listened to Me, declares Jehovah, that you might provoke Me to anger with the work of your hands to your own harm.
Therefore thus says Jehovah of hosts, Because you have not listened to My words,

I will send for and take all the families of the [xref]a[/xref]north, declares Jehovah, that is, for [xref]b[/xref]Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon, My servant, and I will bring them against this land and against its inhabitants and against all these surrounding nations and will utterly destroy them and make them an astonishment and a hissing and an eternal reproach.

[xref]a[/xref]And I will cause the voice of gladness and the voice of joy to perish from them, the voice of the bridegroom and the voice of the bride, the sound of the millstones and the light of the lamp.
And this whole land will become a desolation and a waste, and these nations will serve the king of Babylon [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]seventy years.
verse.note: This word and that in [link]29:10-14[/link] were a comfort to Jeremiah, assuring him that the captivity of Israel would last only seventy years. Some of the captured ones, such as Daniel, would still be alive at the expiration of the seventy years ([link]Dan. 1:21[/link]; [link]6:28[/link]). Just as God gave the people up to captivity, He would bring them back, not as captives but as triumphant warriors.

verse.text: Then after the seventy years have been fulfilled, I will punish the king of Babylon and that nation for their iniquity, declares Jehovah, as well as the land of the Chaldeans, and I will make it an eternal [xref]a[/xref]desolation.
And I will bring upon that land all My words which I have spoken against it, everything written in this book, which Jeremiah prophesied against all the [xref]a[/xref]nations.
For many nations and great kings will make them serve them, even them, and I will recompense them according to their doing and according to the work of their hands.
For thus said Jehovah the God of Israel to me, Take this [xref]a[/xref]cup of the wine of wrath from My hand and make all the nations to whom I am sending you drink it.
And they will drink and stagger and become mad because of the sword which I am sending among them.
And I took the cup from Jehovah's hand and made all the nations to whom Jehovah sent me drink [i]it:[/i]
[xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem and the cities of Judah and her kings, her princes, to make them a desolation, a waste, a hissing and a curse, as it is this day;
Pharaoh, the king of [xref]a[/xref]Egypt, and his servants and his princes and all his people;
And all the mingled people, and all the kings of the land of Uz, and all the kings of the land of the [xref]a[/xref]Philistines (even Ashkelon and Gaza and Ekron and the remnant of Ashdod);
[xref]a[/xref]Edom and [xref]b[/xref]Moab and the children of [xref]c[/xref]Ammon;
And all the kings of [xref]a[/xref]Tyre and all the kings of Sidon and the kings of the islands across the sea;
And Dedan and Tema and Buz and all who cut the corners [i]of their hair;[/i]
And all the kings of Arabia and all the kings of the mingled people who dwell in the wilderness;
And all the kings of Zimri and all the kings of [xref]a[/xref]Elam and all the kings of Media;

And all the kings of the north, near and far, one with another, and all the kingdoms of the earth which are upon the surface of the ground and the king of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sheshach will drink [i]it[/i] after them.
verse.note: I.e., Babylon (cf. [link]51:41[/link]).

verse.text: And you shall say to them, Thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, Drink and be drunk, and vomit and fall, and rise no longer, because of the sword which I am sending among you.
And if they refuse to take the cup from your hand to drink, then you shall say to them, Thus says Jehovah of hosts, You shall surely drink [i]it.[/i]

For I am now [xref]a[/xref]beginning to bring evil on the city which is called by My name, and will you indeed go unpunished? You will not go unpunished, for I am calling for a sword against all the inhabitants of the earth, declares Jehovah of hosts.

Therefore you shall prophesy against them all these words and say to them,[br/][xref]a[/xref]Jehovah will roar from on high, / And He will utter His voice from His holy habitation; / He will roar mightily against His habitation; / He will respond with a shout like those who tread [i]grapes,[/i] / Against all the inhabitants of the earth.

The tumult comes to the ends of the earth, / For Jehovah has a [xref]a[/xref]dispute with the nations. / He is entering into [xref]b[/xref]judgment with all flesh / And will give up the wicked to the sword, / Declares Jehovah.
Thus says Jehovah of hosts, / Evil is now going forth / From nation to nation, / And a great storm wind is being stirred up / From the uttermost parts of the earth.

And those slain by Jehovah on that day from one end of the earth unto the other end of the earth will not be [xref]a[/xref]mourned for or gathered or buried; they will be as dung on the surface of the ground.

Howl, O shepherds, and cry out / And roll [i]in ashes,[/i] O majestic ones of the flock; / For your days of slaughter have been fulfilled, / And I will disperse you, so that you fall like a precious vessel.
And refuge will perish from the shepherds, / And an escape from the majestic ones of the flock.
The sound of the cry of the shepherds! / And the howl of the majestic ones of the flock! / For Jehovah is destroying their pasture;
And the habitations of peace are destroyed / Because of the burning anger of Jehovah.
Like a young [xref]a[/xref]lion He has left His lair, / For their land has become a waste, / Because of the [note]1[/note]oppressing sword / And because of His burning anger.
verse.note: According to the Septuagint and some Hebrew MSS (cf. [link]46:16[/link]; [link]50:16[/link]); others read, fierceness of the oppressor.

verse.text: In the beginning of the reign of [xref]a[/xref]Jehoiakim the son of Josiah, the king of Judah, this word came from Jehovah, saying,

Thus says Jehovah, Stand in the [xref]a[/xref]court of the house of Jehovah and speak to all the cities of Judah, who come to worship in the house of Jehovah, all the words which I command you to speak to them, and do not take away a word.
Perhaps they will listen and turn, every one from his evil way, that I may repent of the evil which I intend to do to them because of the evil of their deeds.
And you shall say to them, Thus says Jehovah, If you will not listen to Me to walk in My law, which I have set before you,
To listen to the words of My servants the prophets, whom I [xref]a[/xref]send to you, rising up early and sending [i]them[/i] — and you have not listened —
Then I will make this house like [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Shiloh, and this city I will make a curse to all the nations of the earth.
verse.note: See note [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].

verse.text: And the priests and the prophets and all the people heard Jeremiah speaking these words in the house of Jehovah.

And when Jeremiah had finished speaking everything that Jehovah had commanded [i]him[/i] to speak unto all the people, the priests and the prophets and all the people seized him, saying, You will surely die!

Why have you prophesied in the name of Jehovah, saying, This house will be like Shiloh and this city will be a desolation, without inhabitant? And all the people were gathered against Jeremiah in the house of Jehovah.
And the princes of Judah heard these things, and they went up from the king's house to the house of Jehovah and took their seat at the entrance of the new gate of [i]the house of[/i] Jehovah.
And the priests and the prophets spoke to the princes and to all the people, saying, A sentence of death on this man! For he has prophesied against this city, as you have heard with your own ears.
Then Jeremiah spoke to all the princes and to all the people, saying, Jehovah sent me to prophesy against this house and against this city all the words which you have heard.
Now therefore [xref]a[/xref]amend your ways and your deeds and listen to the voice of Jehovah your God, and Jehovah will [xref]b[/xref]repent of the evil which He has spoken against you.
But as for me, here I am, in your hands; do with me as is good and right in your eyes.

Only know for certain that if you put me to death, you will bring innocent blood upon yourselves and upon this city and upon her inhabitants; for truly Jehovah has sent me to you to speak all these words in your ears.
Then the princes and all the people said to the priests and to the prophets, This man is not [i]worthy[/i] of a sentence of death, for he has spoken to us in the name of Jehovah our God.
And some of the elders of the land rose up and spoke to all the assembly of the people, saying,

[xref]a[/xref]Micah the Morashtite prophesied in the days of Hezekiah the king of Judah and spoke to all the people of Judah, saying, Thus says Jehovah of hosts,[br/][xref]b[/xref]Zion will be plowed as a field, / And Jerusalem will become a heap of ruins, / And the [xref]c[/xref]mountain of the [note]1[/note]house as the high places of a forest.
verse.note: I.e., the temple.

verse.text: Did Hezekiah the king of Judah and all Judah put him to death? Did he not [xref]a[/xref]fear Jehovah and entreat the favor of Jehovah, and did not Jehovah repent of the evil which He had spoken against them? But we are about to bring a great evil on ourselves.

And there was another man who prophesied in the name of Jehovah, Uriah the son of Shemaiah from Kiriath-jearim, and he prophesied against this city and against this land words like all those of Jeremiah.
And when King Jehoiakim and all his mighty men and all the princes heard his words, the king sought to put him to death; but when Uriah heard, he was afraid and fled and went to Egypt.
And King Jehoiakim sent certain men to Egypt, that is, Elnathan the son of Achbor and men with him to Egypt;
And they brought Uriah out of Egypt and brought him to King Jehoiakim, and he struck him with the sword and threw his corpse into the graves of the common people.
Nevertheless the hand of [xref]a[/xref]Ahikam the son of Shaphan was with Jeremiah, so that he was [note]1[/note]not given into the hands of the people to put him to death.
verse.note: God's goal in sending Jeremiah was to bring Israel back to God directly as the source, the fountain, of living waters ([link]2:13[/link]) that they might receive His dispensing. Although Jeremiah was preserved, because of the different opinions among the people concerning Jeremiah, nothing was attained toward the accomplishing of God's goal. All the different opinions distracted the people from God and kept them away from His dispensing. Distractions are the devil's devices to keep God's people from receiving the divine dispensing.

verse.text: In the beginning of the reign of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Zedekiah the son of Josiah, the king of Judah, this word came to Jeremiah from Jehovah, saying,
verse.note: Many MSS read, Jehoiakim.

verse.text: Thus said Jehovah to me, Make for yourself bonds and [xref]a[/xref]yoke bars, and put them on your neck;

And send them to the king of Edom and to the king of Moab and to the king of the children of Ammon and to the king of Tyre and to the king of Sidon by the hand of the messengers who come to Jerusalem to Zedekiah the king of Judah.
And command them [i]to go[/i] to their masters, saying, Thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel: Thus you shall say to your masters,

It is I who made the [xref]a[/xref]earth, [i]and[/i] the people and the animals who are on the face of the earth, by My great power and by My outstretched arm; and I give it to [xref]b[/xref]whomever it seems right in My own eyes.
And now I have given all these lands into the hand of [xref]a[/xref]Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon, My servant; and I have also given him the beasts of the field to serve him.
And all the nations will serve him and his son and his son's son until the [xref]a[/xref]time of his own land comes, when many nations and great kings will make him serve [i]them.[/i]

But if any nation or kingdom will not serve this Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon and will not put its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon, I will punish that nation with sword and with famine and with pestilence, declares Jehovah, until I have consumed them by his hand.

But as for you, do not listen to your prophets and to your [note]1[/note]diviners and to your dreams and to your [note]1[/note]soothsayers and to your [note]1[/note]sorcerers who speak to you, saying, You will not serve the king of Babylon.
verse.note: The diviners, the soothsayers, and the sorcerers practiced witchcraft, having regular contact with demons. Instead of contacting God, they continually contacted an evil, demonic source. This was the way they lived.

verse.text: For they prophesy [xref]a[/xref]falsehood to you, with the result that you will be removed far from your land; and I will drive you out, and you will perish.
But any nation that will bring its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon and serve him, I will leave in its own land, declares Jehovah, to till it and dwell there.
And I spoke to Zedekiah the king of Judah according to all these words, saying, Bring your necks under the yoke of the king of Babylon, and serve him and his people, and live.
Why will you die, you and your people, by sword, by famine, and by pestilence, as Jehovah has spoken concerning the nation which will not serve the king of Babylon?
And do not listen to the words of the prophets who speak to you, saying, You will not serve the king of Babylon; for they are prophesying [xref]a[/xref]falsehood to you.
For I have not sent them, declares Jehovah; but they prophesy falsely in My name, with the result that I will drive you out and you will perish, you and the prophets who prophesy to you.

And I spoke to the priests and to all this people, saying, Thus says Jehovah, Do not listen to the words of your prophets who prophesy to you, saying, The [xref]a[/xref]vessels of the house of Jehovah will now shortly be brought back from Babylon; for they are prophesying [xref]b[/xref]falsehood to you.
Do not listen to them; serve the king of Babylon and live. Why should this city become a desolation?

But if they are prophets and if the word of Jehovah is with them, let them intercede to Jehovah of hosts that the vessels which are left in the house of Jehovah and in the house of the king of Judah and in Jerusalem may not go to Babylon.
For thus says Jehovah of hosts concerning the [xref]a[/xref]pillars and concerning the sea and concerning the bases and concerning the rest of the vessels which are left in this city,

Which Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon did not take when he took into exile [xref]a[/xref]Jeconiah the son of Jehoiakim, the king of Judah, from Jerusalem to Babylon, and all the nobles of Judah and Jerusalem.
For thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, concerning the vessels which are left in the house of Jehovah and in the house of the king of Judah and in Jerusalem,
They will be carried to Babylon and remain there until the day I visit them, declares Jehovah; then I will bring them up and restore [xref]a[/xref]them to this place.

And in that same year, at the beginning of the reign of Zedekiah the king of Judah, in the fourth year, in the fifth month, Hananiah the son of Azzur, the prophet, who was from Gibeon, spoke to me in the house of Jehovah in the presence of the priests and all the people, saying,
Thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, saying, I have broken the [xref]a[/xref]yoke of the king of Babylon.
Within two full years I will bring back to this place all the [xref]a[/xref]vessels of the house of Jehovah, which Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon took from this place and carried to Babylon.

And Jeconiah the son of Jehoiakim, the king of Judah, and all the exiles from Judah who went to Babylon, I will bring back to this place, declares Jehovah; for I will break the yoke of the king of Babylon.
Then the prophet Jeremiah spoke to the prophet Hananiah in the presence of the priests and in the presence of all the people who were standing in the house of Jehovah.

And the prophet Jeremiah said, [xref]a[/xref]Amen! May Jehovah do so. May Jehovah establish your words which you have prophesied and bring back the vessels of the house of Jehovah and all the exiles from Babylon to this place.
Nevertheless hear now this word which I am about to speak in your ears and in the ears of all the people.
The prophets who were before me and before you since long ago prophesied against many lands and against great kingdoms, of war and of evil and of pestilence.
The prophet who prophesies of peace, when the word of that prophet [xref]a[/xref]comes to pass, then the prophet will be known as one whom Jehovah has truly sent.
Then the prophet Hananiah took the [xref]a[/xref]yoke bar from the neck of the prophet Jeremiah and broke it.

And Hananiah spoke in the presence of all the people, saying, Thus says Jehovah, Even so I will break the [xref]a[/xref]yoke of Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon from the neck of all the nations within two full years. Then the prophet Jeremiah went his way.
And the word of Jehovah came to Jeremiah after the prophet Hananiah had broken the yoke bar from the neck of the prophet Jeremiah, saying,
Go and speak to Hananiah, saying, Thus says Jehovah, You have broken the wooden yoke bars, but you have made in their place iron yoke bars.

For thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, I have put an [xref]a[/xref]iron yoke upon the neck of all these nations that they may serve Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon; and they will serve him. And I have also given the beasts of the field to him.
And the prophet Jeremiah said to the prophet Hananiah, Listen now, O Hananiah, Jehovah has not sent you, and you have made this people trust in [xref]a[/xref]falsehood.
Therefore thus says Jehovah, I will send you from the face of the earth. This year you will die because you have spoken [xref]a[/xref]rebellion against Jehovah.
And the prophet Hananiah died in that very year in the seventh month.

And these are the words of the letter which the prophet Jeremiah sent from Jerusalem to the rest of the elders of the exile and to the priests and to the prophets and to all the people whom Nebuchadnezzar had taken into exile from Jerusalem to Babylon
(After King [xref]a[/xref]Jeconiah and the queen mother and the eunuchs, the princes of Judah, and Jerusalem and the craftsmen and the smiths had gone out from Jerusalem),
By the hand of Elasah the son of Shaphan and Gemariah the son of Hilkiah, whom Zedekiah the king of Judah sent to Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon at Babylon, saying:
Thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, to all the exiles whom I have sent into exile from Jerusalem to Babylon,
Build [xref]a[/xref]houses and dwell [i]in them,[/i] and plant gardens and eat their produce.
Take wives and beget sons and daughters, and take wives for your sons and give your daughters to husbands, that they may bear sons and daughters, and multiply there and do not become few.
And seek the peace of the city where I have sent you into exile, and [xref]a[/xref]pray to Jehovah for it; for in its peace you will have peace.
For thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, Do not let your prophets, who are in your midst, and your diviners deceive you; and do not listen to your dreams, which you cause to be dreamed.
For they prophesy to you falsely in My name; and I have not sent them, declares Jehovah.
For thus says Jehovah, When [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]seventy years are fulfilled for Babylon, I will visit you and establish My good word to you, to bring you back to this place.
verse.note: See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 25[/link].

verse.text: For I know the thoughts that I think about you, declares Jehovah, thoughts of peace and not for evil, to give you a latter end and a hope.
Then you will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]call upon Me and come and pray to Me, and I will listen to you;
verse.note: See note [link]26[sup]2[/sup] in Gen. 4[/link].

verse.text: And you will [xref]a[/xref]seek Me and find [i]Me[/i] if you search for Me with all your heart;

And I will be found by you, declares Jehovah. And I will turn your captivity and gather you from all the nations and from all the places where I have driven you, declares Jehovah, and [xref]a[/xref]bring you back to the place from where I sent you into exile.
If you say, Jehovah has raised up for us prophets in Babylon,
Indeed thus says Jehovah concerning the king who sits on the throne of David and concerning all the people who dwell in this city, your brothers who did not go out with you into exile:
Thus says Jehovah of hosts, I am about to send upon them [xref]a[/xref]sword, famine, and pestilence, and I will make them like vile [xref]b[/xref]figs, which cannot be eaten because of rottenness.

And I will pursue them with sword, with famine, and with pestilence, and I will make them a terror to all the kingdoms of the earth to be a curse and an astonishment and a hissing and a reproach among all the nations where I have driven them;
Because they have not listened to My words, declares Jehovah, which I [xref]a[/xref]sent to them by My servants the prophets, rising up early and sending; but you did not listen, declares Jehovah.
Therefore hear the word of Jehovah, all you exiles whom I sent away from Jerusalem to Babylon.

Thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, concerning Ahab the son of Kolaiah and concerning Zedekiah the son of Maaseiah, who are prophesying to you falsehood in My name, I will deliver them into the hand of Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon, and he will strike them before your eyes.
And because of them a curse will be taken up by all the exiles from Judah who are in Babylon, saying, May Jehovah make you like Zedekiah and like Ahab, whom the king of Babylon roasted in the fire;

Because they have committed folly in Israel and have committed adultery with their neighbors' wives and have spoken a word of falsehood in My name, which I did not command them [i]to do;[/i] indeed I am the One who knows and am witness, declares Jehovah.
And you shall speak to Shemaiah the Nehelamite, saying,

Thus speaks Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, saying, Because you have sent letters in your own name to all the people who are in Jerusalem and to Zephaniah the son of Maaseiah, the priest, and to all the priests, saying,

Jehovah has made you a priest instead of Jehoiada the priest, that there should be officers in the house of Jehovah over every madman who prophesies so that you might put him in the stocks and in the iron collar.
And now why have you not rebuked Jeremiah of Anathoth, who prophesies to you?
For he has sent to us in Babylon, saying, It will be a long time; build houses and dwell [i]in them,[/i] and plant gardens and eat their produce.
And Zephaniah the priest read this letter in the ears of Jeremiah the prophet.
Then the word of Jehovah came to Jeremiah, saying,
Send [i]word[/i] to all the exiles, saying, Thus says Jehovah concerning Shemaiah the Nehelamite, Because Shemaiah has prophesied to you, when I did not send him, and has made you trust in falsehood,

Therefore thus says Jehovah, I will punish Shemaiah the Nehelamite and his seed: He will not have anyone living among this people and will not see the good that I am about to do to My people, declares Jehovah, because he has spoken [xref]a[/xref]rebellion against Jehovah.
The word which came to Jeremiah from Jehovah, saying,
Thus speaks Jehovah the God of Israel, saying, Write in a book all the words which I have spoken to you.

Yes indeed, days are coming, declares Jehovah, when I will [xref]a[/xref]turn the captivity of My people Israel and Judah, says Jehovah, and I will bring them back to the land which I gave to their fathers, and they will possess it.
And these are the words which Jehovah spoke concerning Israel and concerning Judah:
For thus says Jehovah, / We have heard a voice of trembling, / Of fear and not of peace.
Ask now and see / Whether a man can give birth. / Why do I see every man / With his hands on his loins like a [xref]a[/xref]woman about to give birth / And every face turned pale?
Alas! For that [xref]a[/xref]day is great, / And there is none like it; / And it is a time of [note]1[/note]distress for Jacob, / But he will be saved out of it.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Dan. 12[/link].

verse.text: And on that day, declares Jehovah of hosts, I will break his yoke from your neck and tear off your bonds, and strangers will no longer make him serve [i]them.[/i]
But they will serve Jehovah their God and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]David their King, whom I will raise up for them.
verse.note: Referring to Christ, who is the real David (see note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Sam. 7[/link]) and who will be the King in the restoration, i.e., the millennium ([link]Isa. 32:1[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:4, 6[/link]). David was a type of Christ as the King.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Therefore do not fear, O Jacob My servant, declares Jehovah, / And do not be dismayed, O Israel; / For indeed, I will save you from afar, / And your seed from the land of their captivity; / And Jacob will return and be undisturbed and at ease, / And no one will frighten [i]him.[/i]
