God will come in to judge the world in all its aspects and to make a clear distinction between the church, which is today's Israel ([link]Gal. 6:16[/link] and note 4), and every aspect of the world.[br/]Jeremiah prophesied concerning the nations because in His economy God needs them. On the one hand, God needs His chosen people to express Him; on the other hand, He needs another people, the nations, to behold and admire this expression, which is His masterpiece ([link]Eph. 2:10[/link]), the New Jerusalem. The nations around the New Jerusalem in the new heaven and new earth ([link]Rev. 21:24[/link], [link]26[/link]; [link]22:2b[/link]) will eventually come from the nations concerning which Jeremiah and other Old Testament prophets prophesied.

verse.text: Concerning [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Egypt: Concerning the army of [xref]b[/xref]Pharaoh Neco, the king of Egypt, which was by the river Euphrates at Carchemish, which Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon struck down in the [xref]c[/xref]fourth year of Jehoiakim the son of Josiah, the king of Judah:
verse.note: Egypt, symbolically or poetically called Rahab ([link]Psa. 87:4[/link]; [link]Isa. 51:9[/link]), typifies the world of making a living and of enjoyment ([link]Gen. 12:10[/link]; [link]41:57-42:3[/link]; [link]Num. 11:4-6[/link]; [link]Heb. 11:25[/link]), with which Satan, the ruler of the world ([link]John 12:31[/link]), typified by Pharaoh, the ruler of Egypt, occupies and usurps the people chosen by God for His economy ([link]Exo. 1:8-14[/link]). The name [i]Rahab[/i] refers to a monster, to a large sea animal. This indicates that God regards Egypt as a monster, as an ugly, terrifying sea animal.

verse.text: Prepare the buckler and shield, / And draw near to battle.
Harness the horses, / And mount the steeds; / And take your stand with helmets [i]on;[/i] / Polish the spears; / Put on the armor.

Why have I seen [i]it?[/i] / They are dismayed; / They are turning backward; / And their mighty men are crushed and flee in [i]hasty[/i] flight, / And they do not look back; terror is on every side, / Declares Jehovah.
Let not the swift one flee away / And the mighty man escape; / In the north by the river Euphrates / They have stumbled and fallen.
Who is this who rises up like the Nile, / Like rivers whose [xref]a[/xref]waters surge?
Egypt rises up like the Nile, / Even like rivers whose waters surge. / And he says, I will rise up and will cover the land; / I will destroy the city and the inhabitants in it.
Go up, O horses, / And drive furiously, O chariots; / And let the mighty men go forth: / Cush and Put, who handle the shield, / And the [note]1[/note]Ludim, who handle [i]and[/i] bend the bow.
verse.note: Probably the Lydians of Asia Minor.

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]this day belongs to the Lord Jehovah of hosts, / A day of vengeance to avenge Himself on His adversaries; / And the sword will devour and be satisfied, / And it will drink its fill of their blood; / For there is a [xref]b[/xref]sacrifice to the Lord Jehovah of hosts / In the land of the north by the river Euphrates.
Go up to [xref]a[/xref]Gilead and take balm, / O virgin daughter of Egypt. / In vain you have used many medicines — / There is no healing for you.
The nations have heard of your disgrace, / And your cry has filled the earth; / For mighty man has stumbled against mighty man; / Both of them have fallen together.
The word which Jehovah spoke to Jeremiah the prophet about the coming of Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon to strike the land of [xref]a[/xref]Egypt:
Declare in Egypt, and proclaim in Migdol; / Proclaim also in Memphis and in Tahpanhes. / Say, Take your stand, and prepare yourself; / For the sword has devoured all around you.
Why are your mighty men prostrate? / He does not stand, because Jehovah has cast him down.
He made many stumble; / A man even fell against his neighbor; / And they said, Arise and let us return / To our own people and to the land of our birth, / Away from the sword of the oppressor.
There they cried, Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, is but a noise; / He has let the appointed time pass by.
As I live, says the [xref]a[/xref]King, / Whose name is Jehovah of hosts, / Surely as Tabor is among the mountains, / And Carmel is by the sea, so he will come.
Prepare for yourself baggage for captivity, / O inhabitant, O daughter of Egypt; / For Memphis will become a waste, / And it will be burned, without inhabitant.
Egypt is a beautiful heifer; / A [note]1[/note]gadfly from the [xref]a[/xref]north has come [note]2[/note]on her.
verse.note: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon.
According to the Septuagint; the Hebrew text repeats, has come.

verse.text: Also her hired men in her midst / Are like fattened calves. / But they have also turned back; / They have fled together; they did not stand. / For the day of their calamity has come on them, / The time of their punishment.
Her sound is like [i]that of[/i] a serpent going away; / For they go forth in force, / And with axes they come against her, / Like those who fell trees.
They will cut down her forest, declares Jehovah, / Although it is impenetrable; / For they are more numerous than locusts / And are without number.
The daughter of Egypt is put to shame; / She is given into the hand of a people from the north.
Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, says, I will [xref]a[/xref]punish [note]1[/note]Amon of No and Pharaoh and Egypt and her gods and her kings, even Pharaoh and those who trust in him.
verse.note: The most honorable god in Egypt.

verse.text: And I will give them into the hand of those who seek their life, even into the hand of Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon and into the hand of his servants; and [note]1[/note]afterward she will be inhabited as in the days of old, declares Jehovah.
verse.note: According to this word and [link]Isa. 19:19-25[/link] Egypt will have a remnant to be among the restored nations in the new heaven and new earth.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]But as for you, O Jacob My servant, do not [xref]b[/xref]fear; / And do not be dismayed, O Israel. / For indeed I will save you from afar / And your seed from the land of their captivity; / And Jacob will return and be undisturbed / And at ease, and no one will frighten [i]him.[/i]
verse.note: Jeremiah declared God's judgment on Egypt because Israel depended on Egypt, thus offending God. Israel also suffered that judgment; hence, Jeremiah gave Israel the word of comfort in [link]vv. 27-28[/link] (cf. [link]30:10-11[/link]). This word will be fulfilled at the time of the restoration ([link]Matt. 19:28[/link]), in the millennium, the thousand-year kingdom ([link]Rev. 20:4-6[/link]).

verse.text: As for you, O Jacob My servant, do not fear, declares Jehovah, / For I am with you; / For I will make a full end of all the nations / To which I have driven you; / Yet I will not make a [xref]a[/xref]full end of you, / But will correct you in measure / And will by no means leave you unpunished.
The word of Jehovah that came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Philistines before Pharaoh struck Gaza.
verse.note: The Philistines were located alongside the nation of Israel ([link]Exo. 15:14[/link]). They typify the world that is close to the interest of God on earth and attacks and damages the testimony of God on earth to hinder God's economy ([link]Judg. 13:1[/link]; [link]14:4[/link]; [link]1 Sam. 4:3-11[/link]; [link]17:1[/link], [link]4[/link], [link]45-49[/link]). See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Sam. 6[/link].

verse.text: Thus says Jehovah, / See, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]waters are rising up from the [xref]b[/xref]north / And will become an overflowing stream; / And they will overflow the land and all that fills it, / The city and those who dwell in it; / And men will cry out, / And every inhabitant of the land will howl.
verse.note: The army of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon.

verse.text: At the sound of the stamping of the hooves of his stallions, / At the rushing of his chariots, at the rumbling of his wheels, / The fathers will not turn back for [i]their[/i] children, / Because of the feebleness of their hands,

Because of the day which is coming, / To destroy all the Philistines, / To cut off from Tyre and Sidon / Every helper who survives; / For Jehovah will destroy the Philistines, / The remnant of the coastland of Caphtor.
Baldness has come upon Gaza; / Ashkelon has been cut off. / O remnant of their valley, / How long will you cut yourself?
Alas, O [xref]a[/xref]sword of Jehovah, / How long until you are quiet? Put yourself into your sheath; / Rest and be still.
How can [note]1[/note]it be quiet, / When Jehovah has commanded it? / Against Ashkelon and against the seacoast — / There He has appointed it.
verse.note: Lit., you.

verse.text: Concerning [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Moab: / Thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel: / Woe to Nebo, for it is destroyed; / Kiriathaim is put to shame; it is captured; / The lofty retreat is put to shame and dismayed.
verse.note: Moab, the first forefather of the Moabites, was born of Lot through his committing incest with his daughters ([link]Gen. 19:30-38[/link]). Moab as a nation typifies the world of fleshly lust that corrupts and frustrates God's chosen people, through the greedy religionists, from following and walking with God in His holy way ([link]Num. 25:1-5[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 2:15[/link]; [link]Rev. 2:14[/link]). It was Moab who hired Balaam, the Gentile prophet, to stumble the children of Israel ([link]Num. 22:1-21[/link]; [link]Deut. 23:4[/link]).[br][br]The Moabites were not allowed to enter into the assembly of Jehovah even to the tenth generation ([link]Deut. 23:3[/link]). However, Ruth, a Moabitess, became the mother of one of the prominent forefathers of Christ ([link]Matt. 1:5b[/link]) because of her allegiance to Israel in the interest of God ([link]Ruth 1:14-18[/link]). This indicates that although the Moabites were condemned, at a certain time God had compassion on them.

verse.text: The praise of Moab is no more; / In Heshbon they have devised evil against her, [i]saying:[/i] / Come and let us cut her off from being a nation. / You also, O [note]1[/note]Madmen, will be brought to silence; / A sword will go after you.
verse.note: Madmen is a city in Moab.

verse.text: The sound of a cry from Horonaim, / Desolation and great destruction!
Moab is destroyed; / Her young have caused a cry to be heard.
For by the ascent of Luhith / Continual weeping will go up; / For by the descent of Horonaim / They have heard the distress of the cry of destruction.
Flee, save your life, / And be like a shrub in the wilderness.
For because of your trust in your works and in your treasures, / You also will be captured; / And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Chemosh will go forth into exile; / His priests and his princes together.
verse.note: The god of the Moabites ([link]1 Kings 11:33[/link]).

verse.text: And a destroyer will come to every city, / And no city will escape; / The valley will also perish, / And the plateau will be destroyed, / As Jehovah has said.
Give wings to Moab, / That she may [xref]a[/xref]fly [i]and[/i] go away; / And her cities will become a waste, / Without inhabitant in them.
Cursed is he who does the [xref]a[/xref]work of Jehovah [note]1[/note]negligently, / And cursed is he who keeps his sword from blood.
verse.note: Or, deceitfully.

verse.text: Moab has been at ease from his youth; / And he is [xref]a[/xref]settled on his lees / And has not been emptied from vessel to vessel; / Nor has he gone into exile. / Therefore his taste remains in him, / And his scent is not changed.
Therefore indeed, days are coming, declares Jehovah, when I will send pourers to him, and they will pour and empty his vessels and shatter [note]1[/note]his jars.
verse.note: Lit., their.

verse.text: And Moab will be ashamed of Chemosh, as the house of Israel was ashamed of [xref]a[/xref]Bethel, their confidence.
How can you say, We are mighty men / And valiant men for war?
Moab has been destroyed, / And its cities have gone up [i]in smoke,[/i] / And its choice young men have gone down to slaughter, / Declares the [xref]a[/xref]King, whose name is Jehovah of hosts.
The calamity of Moab is near to coming, / And his affliction hastens quickly.
Lament for him, all who are around [i]him[/i] / And all who know his name; / Say, How the strong rod is broken, / The glorious staff.
Come down from glory and sit in thirst, / O daughter who dwells in Dibon, / For the destroyer of Moab has come up against you; / He has destroyed your strongholds.
Stand by the way and watch, / O inhabitant of Aroer; / Ask him who flees and her who escapes, / [i]And[/i] say, What has happened?
Moab is put to shame, for it is shattered. / Howl and cry out; / Declare in Arnon / That Moab is devastated.
And judgment has come upon the land of the Plateau, on Holon and on Jahzah and on Mephaath
And on Dibon and on Nebo and on Beth-diblathaim
And on Kiriathaim and on Beth-gamul and on Beth-meon
And on Kerioth and on Bozrah and on all the cities of the land of Moab, far and near.
The horn of Moab is cut off, and his arm is broken, declares Jehovah.
Make him drunk, because he [xref]a[/xref]magnified himself against Jehovah; so Moab will wallow in his vomit and will also be in derision.
For was not Israel a derision to you? Or was he found among thieves? For as often as you speak of him, you shake [i]your head.[/i]
Leave the cities and dwell in the rock, / O inhabitants of Moab, / And be like a dove who nests / On the sides of the mouth of the pit.
We have heard of the [xref]a[/xref]pride of Moab — / He is extremely proud — / Of his loftiness and his pride and his arrogance / And of the haughtiness of his heart.
I know of his insolence, declares Jehovah; / His boastings are [i]all[/i] untrue; / They have accomplished nothing.
Therefore I will [xref]a[/xref]wail for Moab, / I will even cry out for all Moab; / There will be mourning for the men of Kir-heres.

With more than the weeping of Jazer / I will weep for you, O vine of Sibmah. / Your shoots have crossed over [i]to[/i] the sea; / They have reached as far as the sea, to Jazer; / On your summer fruit and on your vintage / The destroyer has fallen.

Rejoicing and exultation are taken away / From the fruited field and from the land of Moab. / And I have caused the wine from the wine presses to cease; / No one will tread [i]them[/i] with the harvest shout; / The harvest shout will be no harvest shout.

From the cry of Heshbon as far as Elealeh, even as far as Jahaz, they have uttered their voice, from Zoar as far as Horonaim [i]and[/i] to Eglath-shelishiyah; for even the waters of Nimrim will become a devastation.
And I will bring to an end in Moab the one who offers up in high places and burns incense to his gods, declares Jehovah.
Therefore My heart will moan for Moab like flutes; for the men of Kir-heres My heart will also moan like flutes. As a result, the abundance he has produced has perished.
For every head is bald, and every beard is shaved off; there are cuts on all the hands, and sackcloth on the loins.
On all the roofs of Moab and in her open squares there is wailing everywhere, for I have broken Moab like a [xref]a[/xref]vessel which no one desires, declares Jehovah.
How it is shattered! they howl. How Moab has turned his back in shame! So Moab has become a derision and a terror to all who are around him.
For thus says Jehovah, / One will swoop down like an [xref]a[/xref]eagle / And spread its [xref]b[/xref]wings against Moab.
[note]1[/note]Kerioth is captured, / And the strongholds are seized, / And the heart of the mighty men of Moab in that day / Will be like the heart of a woman in labor.
verse.note: Or, The cities are captured.

verse.text: And Moab will be destroyed from being a people, / Because he magnified himself against Jehovah.
[xref]a[/xref]Dread, pit, and snare / Are upon you, O inhabitant of Moab, / Declares Jehovah.

He who flees from dread / Will fall into the pit, / And he who comes up out of the pit / Will be taken in the snare; / For I will bring upon her, upon Moab, / The year of their punishment, declares Jehovah.

In the shadow of Heshbon / Those who flee stand without strength; / [xref]a[/xref]For fire has gone forth from Heshbon / And a flame from the midst of Sihon; / And it has consumed the corner of Moab / And the top of the head of the sons of tumult.
Woe to you, O Moab! / The people of Chemosh have perished, / For your sons have been taken captive, / And your daughters [i]have gone[/i] into captivity.
[note]1[/note]But I will [xref]a[/xref]turn again the captivity of Moab / In the last days, declares Jehovah. / Thus far is the judgment of Moab.
verse.note: As indicated here, Moab will receive God's compassion and have a remnant among the restored nations in the new heaven and new earth ([link]Rev. 21:24[/link], [link]26[/link]; [link]22:2b[/link]). The same is true of Ammon ([link]49:6[/link]). See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 46[/link].

verse.text: Concerning the children of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Ammon: / Thus says Jehovah, / Does Israel have no sons? / Or has he no heir? / Why has [note]2[/note]Malcam possessed Gad, / And [i]why[/i] do his people dwell in his cities?
verse.note: Like Moab, Ammon was born of Lot through his committing incest with his daughters ([link]Gen. 19:30-38[/link]). The nation of Ammon typifies the world of fleshly lust that fights against God's chosen people and misleads them into idolatry ([link]Judg. 11:12[/link]; [link]1 Sam. 12:12a[/link]; [link]2 Chron. 20:10-11[/link]; [link]Psa. 83:4-8[/link]; [link]1 Kings 11:5[/link], [link]7[/link]).
Perhaps another form of [i]Milcom,[/i] the name of the god of the Ammonites ([link]1 Kings 11:33[/link]). So also in [link]v. 3[/link].

verse.text: Therefore indeed, days are coming, declares Jehovah, / When I will cause the alarm of war to be heard / Against Rabbah of the children of Ammon. / And it will become a mound of desolation, / And its villages will be burned with fire. / And Israel will dispossess those who dispossess him, / Says Jehovah.

Howl, O Heshbon, for Ai has been destroyed; / Cry out, O daughters of Rabbah. / Gird yourselves with sackcloth [i]and[/i] wail, / And run to and fro among the enclosures; / For Malcam will go into [xref]a[/xref]exile, / Together with his priests and his princes.
Why do you boast in your valleys? / Your valley is flowing away, / O apostate daughter, / Who trusts in her treasures, [i]saying,[/i] / Who will come against me?
I will bring dread upon you, / Declares the Lord Jehovah of hosts, / From all around you; / And each one will be driven out headlong, / And no one will gather him who flees.
[note]1[/note]But afterward I will [xref]a[/xref]turn again / The captivity of the children of Ammon, / Declares Jehovah.
verse.note: See note [link]47[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 48[/link].

verse.text: Concerning [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Edom: / Thus says Jehovah of hosts, / Is there no more [xref]b[/xref]wisdom in Teman? / Has counsel perished from those who understand? / Is their wisdom spent?
verse.note: Edom was a nation of the descendants of Esau, the twin brother of Jacob ([link]Gen. 36:1[/link]). Esau was hated by God and destined by God to serve his younger brother, and he struggled in the flesh against his brother ([link]v. 10a[/link]; [link]Gen. 25:21-26a[/link]; [link]Mal. 1:3a[/link]; [link]Rom. 9:13b[/link]; [link]1 Kings 11:14-16[/link]; [link]2 Kings 8:20[/link], [link]22[/link]; [link]Psa. 83:4-6[/link]; [link]137:7[/link]; [link]Num. 20:21[/link]). Thus, the nation of Edom typifies the world of the old and fleshly man who struggles against the God-chosen and spiritual people (cf. [link]Gal. 4:29[/link]; [link]5:17[/link]).

verse.text: Flee, turn back, dwell in hidden places, / O inhabitants of Dedan, / For I will bring the calamity of Esau upon him / At the time I punish him.
[xref]a[/xref]If the grape gatherers came to you, / Would they not leave gleanings? / If thieves [i]came[/i] by night, / Would they not destroy [i]only[/i] enough for themselves?
But I have stripped Esau bare; / I have exposed his secret places, / And he is not able to conceal himself. / His seed and his brothers are destroyed, / And his neighbors and he are no more.
Leave your [note]1[/note]orphans behind; I will preserve [i]them[/i] alive, / And let your [note]1[/note]widows trust in Me.
verse.note: Even with a people such as the Edomites, God is very concerned for the widows and the orphans and desires that they, and all human beings, trust in Him (cf. [link]1 Tim. 2:3-4[/link]).

verse.text: For thus says Jehovah, Those whose judgment was not to drink the [xref]a[/xref]cup will certainly drink it. And will you by any means be left unpunished? You will not be left unpunished, for you will certainly drink it.
For I have sworn by Myself, declares Jehovah, that [xref]a[/xref]Bozrah will become a waste, a reproach, a ruin and a curse; and all her cities will become eternal desolations.
[xref]a[/xref]I have heard a report from Jehovah, / And an envoy is sent among the nations, [i]saying,[/i] / Gather yourselves together, and come against her, / And arise for war.
For, indeed, I have made you small among the nations, / Despised among men.

Your terribleness, the pride of your heart, / Has beguiled you, / O you who dwell in the clefts of the rock, / Who grasp the height of the hill. / Though you make your nest as high as an eagle's, / I will bring you down from there, declares Jehovah.
And Edom will become an astonishment; everyone who passes by her will be astonished and will hiss at all her wounds.
As when [xref]a[/xref]Sodom and Gomorrah were overthrown with its neighbors, says Jehovah, no one will dwell there, nor will a son of man sojourn in her.

[xref]a[/xref]Indeed, one will come up like a lion from the [xref]b[/xref]majesty of the Jordan against a secure habitation, for I will suddenly make them run away from her; and whoever is chosen I will appoint over her. For who is like Me? And who can appoint Me a time? And who is that shepherd who can stand before Me?

Therefore hear the counsel of Jehovah, which He purposed against Edom, and His thoughts, which He has thought against the inhabitants of Teman: Surely they will drag them off, the little ones of the flock; surely He will make their habitation a desolation because of them.
The earth quaked at the sound of their fall. There is a cry; the sound of it has been heard in the Red Sea.

Indeed, He will mount up and swoop down like an [xref]a[/xref]eagle, and spread out His wings over [note]1[/note]Bozrah; and the heart of the mighty men of Edom in that day will be like the heart of a woman in [xref]b[/xref]labor.
verse.note: At the war of Armageddon Christ will come to judge the nations from Bozrah, the capital of Edom. The Lord Jesus will come back first to Bozrah, and He will tread the great winepress from Bozrah to Armageddon, destroying Antichrist and all the evil armies of the world gathered there ([link]Rev. 14:17-20[/link]; [link]16:12-16[/link]; [link]19:11-15[/link], [link]19-21[/link]; [link]Isa. 63:1-6[/link]; [link]Joel 3:1-2[/link], [link]9-13[/link]). See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Isa. 63[/link].

verse.text: Concerning [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Damascus: / Hamath and Arpad are put to shame / Because they have heard an evil report. / They melt; anxiety is on the sea; / It cannot be quiet.
verse.note: Damascus was a part of Syria ([link]2 Sam. 8:5[/link]). It was close to Israel and had dealings and wars with Israel ([link]1 Kings 15:18-21[/link]; [link]19:15-16[/link]; [link]2 Kings 16:7-16[/link]; [link]1 Kings 11:23-25[/link]; [link]1 Chron. 18:5-6[/link]; [link]2 Chron. 24:23[/link]). Damascus typifies the world that is close to and involved with the kingdom of God.

verse.text: Damascus has become feeble; / She has turned to flee, / And panic has taken hold of her; / Pain and anguish seize her, / Like a woman [xref]a[/xref]giving birth.
How the city of praise is not forsaken, / The town of My joy.
Therefore her young men will fall in her open squares, / And all the men of war will be silenced in that day, declares Jehovah of hosts.
And I will set fire to the wall of Damascus, / And it will consume the palaces of Ben-hadad.

Concerning [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Kedar and the kingdoms of [note]1[/note]Hazor, which Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon struck down:[br/]Thus says Jehovah:[br/]Arise, go up against Kedar, / And destroy the children of the east.
verse.note: Kedar and the kingdoms of Hazor are Arabia ([link]Isa. 21:13-17[/link]; [link]Ezek. 27:21[/link]). The people of Kedar were the descendants of Ishmael ([link]Gen. 25:13[/link]), and they were nomadic ([link]Psa. 120:5[/link]; [link]S.S. 1:5[/link]; [link]Isa. 60:7[/link]). Hazor was very much involved with Israel ([link]Josh. 11:10-13[/link]; [link]Judg. 4:2-3[/link]; [link]1 Sam. 12:9[/link]). Arabia typifies the world that mixes with the people of God.

verse.text: And they will take away their tents and their flocks; / Their curtains and all their vessels / And their camels they will carry away for themselves, / And they will call out to one another, Terror is on every side!

Flee, wander far away, dwell in hidden places, / O inhabitants of Hazor, declares Jehovah; / For Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon / Has taken counsel against you / And has devised a plan against you.
Arise, go up against a nation without care, / One that dwells securely, declares Jehovah. / It has no gates and bars; / They dwell alone.

And their camels will become plunder, / And the multitude of their livestock spoil; / And I will scatter those who cut the corners [i]of their beards[/i] into every wind, / And I will bring their calamity from every side of them, / Declares Jehovah.
And Hazor will become a [xref]a[/xref]habitation of jackals, / An eternal desolation; / No one will dwell there; / Neither will a son of man sojourn in it.
The word of Jehovah which came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Elam, in the beginning of the reign of Zedekiah the king of Judah, saying,
verse.note: The forefather of the Elamites was a son of Shem ([link]Gen. 10:22[/link]). The nation of Elam was once a province of Media, with the city of Shushan (Susa) as its capital ([link]Dan. 8:2[/link]; [link]Esth. 1:2[/link]). The Elamites were enemies of Israel ([link]Ezra 4:8-9[/link]), and in ancient times the king of Elam was defeated by Abraham ([link]Gen. 14:1[/link], [link]17[/link]). Hence, Elam typifies the world that is the enemy of God's chosen people ([link]John 15:19[/link]).

verse.text: Thus says Jehovah of hosts, / I am about to break the bow of Elam, / The chief part of their might.

And I will bring against Elam [xref]a[/xref]four winds / From the four ends of the heavens, / And I will scatter them into all these winds, / And there will not be a nation / To which those who are driven out from Elam will not go.

And I will cause Elam to be dismayed before their enemies / And before those who seek their life; / And I will bring evil upon them, / Even My burning anger, declares Jehovah. / And I will send the sword after them, / Until I make an end of them.
And I will set My throne in Elam, / And I will destroy king and princes from there, / Declares Jehovah.
[note]1[/note]But in the last days, / I will [xref]a[/xref]turn again the captivity of Elam, / Declares Jehovah.
verse.note: This word assures that Elam will be a part of the restored nations around the New Jerusalem in the new heaven and new earth ([link]Rev. 21:24[/link], [link]26[/link]; [link]22:2b[/link]). See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 46[/link].

verse.text: The word which Jehovah spoke concerning [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Babylon, concerning the land of the Chaldeans, through Jeremiah the prophet:
verse.note: The origin and initiation of Babylon was Babel ([link]Gen. 11:7-9[/link]). Babel was built by Nimrod, a descendant of Ham, and was the beginning of human government on earth formed in opposition to God ([link]Gen. 10:6-11[/link]; [link]Dan. 2:31-32[/link], [link]38[/link]). It was a land full of idols, where man worshipped idols, exalted man's self, and opposed God ([link]v. 38b[/link]; [link]Josh. 24:2[/link]; [link]Gen. 11:3-4[/link]). Babel had its continuation in Babylon, which, in the sight of God, is the consummation of human government. Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, was even identified with Satan as Satan's embodiment ([link]Isa. 14:4[/link], [link]11-15[/link]). It was this Babylon that destroyed God's holy city and His holy temple and carried God's holy people and the vessels of God's temple into captivity ([link]2 Chron. 36:17-20[/link]). The coming restored Roman Empire under Antichrist, and the Roman Church, will both, in the spiritual sense, be called Babylon the Great ([link]Rev. 17:5[/link]; [link]18:2[/link]). Hence, Babylon typifies the world, both physically and spiritually, that worships idols, exalts man, and rebels against God to the uttermost, all of which was or will be utterly destroyed by God ([link]51:11[/link]; [link]Rev. 14:8[/link]; [link]16:19b[/link]; [link]17:16[/link]; [link]18:8-10[/link]).[br][br]God will judge Babylon to such an extent that nothing of Babylon will remain in the universe. Both Isaiah and Jeremiah prophesied that once Babylon has been destroyed, it will not be restored ([link]Isa. 14:22-23[/link]; [link]Jer. 50:39[/link]; [link]51:62[/link]). When God destroys both the religious and the political Babylon at the end of the age, that will be the end of the judgment on Babylon prophesied in [link]chs. 50-51[/link]. After this, there will be no more human government on earth. See [link]Dan. 2:32-34[/link] and notes.

verse.text: Declare among the nations and proclaim; / Lift up a banner, proclaim [i]it.[/i] / Do not conceal [i]it, but[/i] say, / [xref]a[/xref]Babylon is captured; / [note]1[/note]Bel is put to shame; / [note]1[/note]Merodach is shattered; / Her images are put to shame; / Her idols are dismayed.
verse.note: Two Babylonian idols, Bel being the chief idol ([link]Isa. 46:1[/link]).

verse.text: For a [note]1[/note]nation has come up against her from the [xref]a[/xref]north; / It will make her land a waste, / And there will be [xref]b[/xref]no inhabitant in it; / Both man and beast have fled; they are gone away.
verse.note: The Medes ([link]51:11[/link], [link]28[/link]).

verse.text: In those days and at that time, declares Jehovah, / The children of Israel will come, / [i]Both[/i] they and the children of Judah [xref]a[/xref]together; / They will go along with [xref]b[/xref]weeping as they go, / And they will [xref]c[/xref]seek Jehovah their God.
They will ask for the way to Zion / With their faces toward it, [i]saying:[/i] / Come and let us join ourselves to Jehovah / In an eternal [xref]a[/xref]covenant that will not be forgotten.

My people are lost [xref]a[/xref]sheep; / Their shepherds have led them astray; / They have made them turn aside on the mountains; / They have gone from mountain to hill; / They have forgotten their resting place.

All who found them have devoured them, / And their adversaries have said, We are not guilty, / Because they have sinned against Jehovah, / The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]habitation of righteousness, / Even Jehovah, the [xref]b[/xref]hope of their fathers.
verse.note: God is the habitation, the dwelling place, of His chosen people ([link]Deut. 33:27[/link]; [link]Psa. 90:1[/link]; [link]1 John 4:16[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:22[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Flee from the midst of Babylon, / And go out from the land of the Chaldeans, / And be as male goats / Before the flock.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Isa. 48[/link].

verse.text: For I am about to stir up and bring up against Babylon / An assembly of great nations from the land of the north; / And they will set themselves in array against her, / And she will be taken captive from there. / Their arrows will be like those of an expert mighty man; / None will return empty-handed.
And Chaldea will become spoil; / All those who spoil her will be satisfied, declares Jehovah.
Because you rejoiced, because you exulted, / O you who plunder My [xref]a[/xref]inheritance, / Because you spring about as a threshing heifer, / And you neigh like stallions,
Your mother has been greatly ashamed; / She who bore you has become a reproach: / Indeed, she has become the last of the nations, / A wilderness, a dry land and a desert.

Because of the wrath of Jehovah she will not be inhabited, / But she will become a complete [xref]a[/xref]desolation; / For every one who passes by Babylon will be astonished / And will hiss at all her wounds.
Set yourselves in array against Babylon all around, / All those who bend the bow; / Shoot at her; spare no arrow; / Because she has sinned against Jehovah;

Raise a shout against her all around. / She has surrendered; her buttresses have fallen, / Her walls have been torn down; / For this is the vengeance of Jehovah: / Take [note]1[/note]vengeance on her; / [xref]a[/xref]As she has done, so do to her.
verse.note: In addition to destroying the nation of Israel, the people of Israel, the holy temple of God, the holy city of God, and the holy land of God, Nebuchadnezzar with the Babylonian army captured the holy vessels, which were used to serve God in the temple, and brought a great part of these vessels to Babylon and put them in the temple of his god ([link]2 Chron. 36:7[/link], [link]18[/link]; [link]Dan. 1:1-2[/link]). This insulted God to the uttermost and was the reason that God's verdict on Babylon is described as His vengeance ([link]v. 28[/link]; [link]51:11[/link]). See [link]Dan. 5[/link] and notes.

verse.text: Cut off the sower from Babylon, / And the one who handles a sickle in the time of harvest;[br/]Because of the sword of the oppressor / Each one will turn to his people, / And each one flee to his own land.

Israel is a scattered sheep; / Lions have driven [i]him[/i] away.[br/]First the [xref]a[/xref]king of Assyria devoured him, and last this [xref]b[/xref]Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon has gnawed his bones.
Therefore thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel: I will punish the king of Babylon and his land, as I punished the king of [xref]a[/xref]Assyria.
And I will bring Israel back to his [xref]a[/xref]habitation, / And he will feed on Carmel and Bashan, / And in the hill country of Ephraim and in Gilead / He will satisfy his soul.

In those days and at that time, declares Jehovah, / The [xref]a[/xref]iniquity of Israel will be sought, but there will be none; / And the sin of Judah, but it will not be found; / For I will forgive those whom I will leave as a remnant.

Go up against her, against the land of [note]1[/note]Merathaim / And against the inhabitants of Pekod. / Desolate and utterly destroy them, declares Jehovah, / And do according to all that I commanded you.
verse.note: A region of Babylon, the name of which also means [i]double rebellion.[/i] "Some take the word as a symbolic name of Babylon" (Darby).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]The sound of war is in the land, / And great destruction.
How the [xref]a[/xref]hammer of the whole earth / Is cut down and broken! / How Babylon has become an astonishment / Among the nations!
I have set a snare for you, and you also have been taken captive, / O Babylon, and you did not know; / You were found, and you also were seized, / Because you engaged in war with Jehovah.
Jehovah has opened His armory / And has brought out the weapons of His wrath, / For this is the work of the Lord Jehovah of hosts / Against the land of the Chaldeans.
Come against her from every side; / Open her granaries. / Pile her up like heaps; / Destroy her utterly; / Let nothing of her remain.
Slay all her oxen; / Let them go down to slaughter.[br/]Woe to them, for their day has come, / The time of their punishment.
There is a sound of those who flee and escape / From the land of Babylon, / To [xref]a[/xref]declare in Zion / The vengeance of Jehovah our God, / The [note]1[/note]vengeance for His temple.
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Summon [note]1[/note]archers against Babylon, / All those who bend the bow. / Encamp against her all around; / Let there be no escape. / [xref]a[/xref]Recompense her according to her work; / According to all that she has done, so do to her. / For she has acted proudly against Jehovah, / Against the Holy One of Israel.
verse.note: Others read, many.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Therefore her young men will fall in her open squares, / And all her men of war will be silenced in that day, / Declares Jehovah.
[xref]a[/xref]Indeed, I am against you, O [note]1[/note]Pride, / Declares the Lord Jehovah of hosts; / For your day has come, / The time that I punish you.
verse.note: The noun, here and in [link]v. 32[/link], is a personified reference to Babylon.

verse.text: And Pride will stumble and fall, / And there will be no one to raise him up. / And I will kindle a fire in his cities, / And it will devour all that is around him.
Thus says Jehovah of hosts, / The children of Israel / And the children of Judah are oppressed together; / And all who took them captive held them fast; / They refused to let them go.
Their [xref]a[/xref]Redeemer is strong; / Jehovah of hosts is His name. / He will surely plead their cause, / That He may give rest to the land / But trouble to the inhabitants of Babylon.
The sword is against the Chaldeans, declares Jehovah, / And against the inhabitants of Babylon / And against her princes and against her wise men.
The sword is against the liars, and they will become fools; / The sword is against her mighty men, and they will be dismayed.

The sword is against [note]1[/note]their horses and against [note]1[/note]their chariots / And against all the mingled people who are in her midst, / And they will become [i]like[/i] women. / The sword is against her treasuries, / And they will be plundered.
verse.note: Lit., his.

verse.text: Drought is upon her waters, / And they will dry up; / For it is a land of graven images, / And they are mad over terrifying idols.

Therefore desert [xref]a[/xref]animals will dwell there with hyenas, / And ostriches will dwell in her. / It will [xref]b[/xref]not be inhabited forever; / It will not be dwelt in from generation to generation.
As when God overthrew [xref]a[/xref]Sodom / And Gomorrah with its neighbors, / Declares Jehovah, / So no one will dwell there; / Nor will a son of man sojourn in it.
[xref]a[/xref]A people is now coming from the [xref]b[/xref]north, / And a great nation and many kings / Are stirring from the uttermost parts of the earth.
They grasp bow and spear; / They are cruel and have no mercy. / Their voice roars like the sea, / And they ride upon horses, / Set in array as a man for battle / Against you, O daughter of Babylon.
The king of Babylon has heard the report about them, / And his hands are feeble; / Distress has seized him, / Pain like a woman in [xref]a[/xref]childbirth.

[xref]a[/xref]Indeed, one will come up like a lion / From the [xref]b[/xref]majesty of the Jordan against a secure habitation; / For I will suddenly make them run away from her; / And whoever is chosen I will appoint over her. / For who is like Me? And who can appoint Me a time? / And who is that shepherd who can stand before Me?

Therefore hear the counsel of Jehovah, / Which He purposed against [xref]a[/xref]Babylon, / And His thoughts, which He has thought / Against the land of the Chaldeans: / Surely they will drag them off, the little ones of the flock; / Surely He will make [i]their[/i] habitation a desolation because of them.
At the sound of Babylon being seized / The earth trembles, / And a cry is heard among the nations.
Thus says Jehovah,[br/]I will stir up against Babylon and against the inhabitants of [note]1[/note]Leb-kamai / A destroying wind.
verse.note: I.e., Chaldea. The words mean [i]the heart of those who rise up against Me.[/i]

verse.text: And I will send [note]1[/note]strangers against Babylon, and they will winnow her, / And they will empty her land / When they come against her from every side / In the evil day.
verse.note: Or, winnowers.

verse.text: Against him who bends, let the archer bend his bow, / And against him who stands up in his armor; / And let them not spare her young men, / But let them utterly destroy all her army.
And they will fall down slain in the land of the Chaldeans / And pierced through in her streets.
For neither Israel nor Judah is forsaken / By his God, by Jehovah of hosts; / But [note]1[/note]their land is full of guilt / Against the Holy One of Israel.
verse.note: I.e., the land of the Chaldeans.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Flee from the midst of Babylon, / And let each man save his life; / Do not be cut off in her iniquity; / For this is a time of vengeance to Jehovah; / He will give full recompense to her.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Isa. 48[/link].

verse.text: Babylon has been a golden [xref]a[/xref]cup in Jehovah's hand / That has made all the earth drunk. / The nations have drunk of her [xref]b[/xref]wine; / Therefore the nations have become mad.
Suddenly Babylon has [xref]a[/xref]fallen and become broken; / Howl over her; / Take balm for her pain, / If perhaps she may be healed.

We tried to heal Babylon, but she is not healed; / [xref]a[/xref]Forsake her, and let each one of us go to his own land; / For her judgment has reached to [xref]b[/xref]heaven / And has been lifted up to the clouds.
Jehovah has brought forth our [xref]a[/xref]righteousnesses; / Come and let us [xref]b[/xref]relate in Zion / The work of Jehovah our God.

Polish the arrows, / Take up the shields.[br/]Jehovah has stirred up the spirit of the kings of the [xref]a[/xref]Medes, because His purpose is against Babylon, to destroy her; for this is the [note]1[/note]vengeance of Jehovah, the vengeance for His temple.
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 50[/link].

verse.text: Lift up a standard against the walls of Babylon; / Make the watch strong. / Set the watchmen; / Prepare the ambushers; / For Jehovah has both purposed and done / What He spoke against the inhabitants of Babylon.
O you who dwell by many [xref]a[/xref]waters, / Abundant in treasures, / Your end has come, / The measure of your unjust gain.
Jehovah of hosts has sworn by Himself, / I will surely fill you with men like [xref]a[/xref]locusts, / And they will raise a shout of victory over you.
[xref]a[/xref]It is He who made the earth by His power, / Who established the world by His wisdom, / And by His understanding He [xref]b[/xref]stretched out the heavens.

When He utters His voice, there is a tumult of waters in the heavens, / [xref]a[/xref]And He causes the vapors to rise from the ends of the earth; / He makes lightning for the rain / And brings forth wind from His treasuries.
Every man is stupid, without knowledge; / Every goldsmith is put to shame by [i]his[/i] idol; / For his molten image is falsehood, / And there is no breath in them.
They are [xref]a[/xref]vanity, the work of delusion; / At the time of their punishment they will perish.
The [xref]a[/xref]Portion of Jacob is not like these; / For He is the One who formed everything, / And [i]Israel is[/i] the tribe of His inheritance; / Jehovah of hosts is His name.
[i]He says,[/i] You are My [xref]a[/xref]hammer, / My weapons of war; / And with you I will shatter nations, / And with you I will destroy kingdoms,
And with you I will shatter the horse and his rider, / And with you I will shatter the chariot and its rider,
And with you I will shatter man and woman, / And with you I will shatter old man and young, / And with you I will shatter young man and virgin,
And with you I will shatter the shepherd and his flock, / And with you I will shatter the farmer and his yoke [i]of oxen,[/i] / And with you I will shatter governors and officials.
And I will [xref]a[/xref]repay Babylon / And all the inhabitants of Chaldea / With all their evil which they have done / In Zion before your eyes, declares Jehovah.

Indeed, I am against you, O mountain of destruction, / Declares Jehovah, / Which destroys the whole earth; / And I will stretch out My hand upon you / And roll you down from the rocks / And make you a burning mountain.
And they will not take from you a stone for the corner / Or a stone for the foundations; / For you will be an eternal [xref]a[/xref]desolation, declares Jehovah.

Lift up a standard in the land; / Blow a trumpet among the nations; / Prepare the nations against her; / Summon against her the kingdoms of Ararat, Minni, and Ashkenaz; / Appoint an officer against her; / Bring up the horses like terrifying locusts.
Prepare the nations against her, / The kings of the [xref]a[/xref]Medes, / [note]1[/note]Their governors and all [note]1[/note]their officials, / And all the land of [note]2[/note]their dominion.
verse.note: Lit., Her.
Lit., his.

verse.text: And the land trembles and writhes, / For the purposes of Jehovah against Babylon stand, / To make the land of Babylon a waste, / [xref]a[/xref]Without inhabitant.
The mighty men of Babylon have ceased fighting; / They remain in strongholds; / Their might has failed; they have become like women. / Her dwellings are on fire; her bars are broken.
Runner runs to meet runner, / And messenger to meet messenger, / To announce to the king of Babylon / That his city has been captured from end [i]to end.[/i]
And the crossing places have been seized, / And they burn the marshes with fire, / And the men of war are terrified.
For thus says Jehovah of hosts, the God of Israel, / The daughter of Babylon is like a threshing floor / At the time when it is trodden; / Yet a little while and the time of harvest will come to her.

Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon has devoured me; / He has crushed me; / He has made me an empty vessel; / He has swallowed me up like a dragon; / He has filled his stomach with my delicacies; / He has washed me out.
The violence done to me and my flesh be on Babylon! / The inhabitant of Zion will say; / And my blood be upon the inhabitants of Chaldea! / Jerusalem will say.
Therefore thus says Jehovah, / I will indeed plead your cause / And execute vengeance for you; / And I will dry up her sea / And make her fountain dry.
And Babylon will become a heap of ruins, / A [xref]a[/xref]habitation of jackals, / An astonishment and a hissing, / Without inhabitant.
They will roar together like young lions; / They will growl like lions' whelps.
When they are inflamed, I will set out their drink; / And I will make them drunk, that they may be merry / And sleep an eternal sleep / And not wake up, declares Jehovah.
And I will bring them down like lambs to the slaughter, / Like rams with male goats.
How Sheshach has been captured, / And the praise of all the earth seized! / How Babylon has become an astonishment / Among the nations!
The sea has come up over Babylon; / She is covered with the multitude of its waves.
Her cities have become a waste, / A dry land and a desert, / A land in which no one dwells, / Through which no person passes.
And I will punish [note]1[/note]Bel in Babylon / And bring what he has swallowed out of his mouth; / And the nations will not stream unto him any longer; / Even the wall of Babylon will fall down.
verse.note: A Babylonian god ([link]Isa. 46:1[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Come out from the midst of her, My people, / And let each man save his life / From the burning anger of Jehovah.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Isa. 48[/link].

verse.text: And lest your heart faint / And you become afraid at the report that will be heard in the land — / For the report will come in [i]one[/i] year; / And after that a report in [i]another[/i] year / And violence in the earth, / Ruler against ruler —
Therefore indeed, days are coming, / When I will punish the idols of Babylon; / And her whole land will be put to shame, / And all her slain will fall in her midst.
And the heavens and the earth and all which is in them / Will give a [xref]a[/xref]ringing shout over Babylon; / For out of the north the destroyers will come against her, / Declares Jehovah.
Babylon is also to fall [i]for[/i] the slain of Israel, / As all the slain of the earth have fallen for Babylon.
You who have escaped the sword, / Go [i]and[/i] do not stand still; / Remember Jehovah from afar, / And let [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem come up in your heart.
We have been put to shame, for we have heard reproach; / Disgrace has covered our faces; / For strangers have come / Into the holy places of the house of Jehovah.
Therefore indeed, days are coming, / Declares Jehovah, / When I will punish her idols, / And throughout her land the wounded will groan.
Though Babylon mount up to the [xref]a[/xref]heavens, / And though she fortify the height of her strength, / Destroyers will come from Me to her, / Declares Jehovah.
verse.xref: Isa. 14:13-14; Jer. 49:16; Amos 9:2; Obad. 4; cf. Luke 10:15

verse.text: The sound of a cry from Babylon, / And great destruction from the land of the Chaldeans!
For Jehovah is destroying Babylon, / And He will cause the loud voice to perish from her. / And [note]1[/note]their waves roar like many waters; / The noise of their voice is raised.
verse.note: I.e., the invaders.

verse.text: For a destroyer has come upon her, upon Babylon, / And her mighty men are taken captive; / Their bows are broken into pieces; / For Jehovah is a [xref]a[/xref]God of recompense; / He will repay in full.

And I will make her princes and her wise men drunk, / Her governors and her officials and her mighty men; / And they will sleep an eternal sleep / And not wake up, declares the King, / Whose name is Jehovah of hosts.

Thus says Jehovah of hosts, / The broad walls of Babylon will be utterly laid bare; / Her high gates will be burned with fire. / So the peoples will have labored in vain; / And the nations, only for fire; and they will have wearied themselves.

The word which Jeremiah the prophet commanded Seraiah the son of Neriah, the son of Mahseiah, when he went with [xref]a[/xref]Zedekiah the king of Judah to Babylon in the fourth year of his reign. (Now Seraiah was quartermaster.)
And Jeremiah wrote in a book all the evil that would come on Babylon, even all these words that are written concerning Babylon.
And Jeremiah said to Seraiah, When you come to Babylon, see that you read all these words;
And say, O Jehovah, You have spoken concerning this place, to cut it off, so that nothing should dwell in it, neither man nor animal, for it will be an eternal desolation.
And as soon as you have finished reading this book, you shall bind a [xref]a[/xref]stone to it and cast it into the midst of the Euphrates,
And say, Thus Babylon will sink and will not rise up because of the evil which I will bring upon it, and they will weary themselves. Thus far are the words of Jeremiah.

[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he began to reign, and he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem; and his mother's name was Hamutal, the daughter of Jeremiah, from Libnah.
verse.note: This chapter, a supplement to the history of Israel's captivity, is the definite fulfillment of Jeremiah's prophecies as a justification to this genuine prophet and a condemnation to the false prophets ([link]ch. 29[/link]).

verse.text: And he did what was evil in the sight of Jehovah, according to all that Jehoiakim had done.
For [i]it was[/i] through the anger of Jehovah [i]that this[/i] came to pass in Jerusalem and Judah until He cast them out from His presence. And Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.

[xref]a[/xref]And in the ninth year of his reign, in the tenth month, on the tenth of the month, Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon came, he and his whole army, against Jerusalem and encamped against it; and they built a siege wall against it all around.
So the city came under siege until the eleventh year of King Zedekiah.
In the fourth month, on the ninth day of the month, the famine was so severe within the city that there was no food for the people of the land.

Then the city was breached, and all the men of war fled; and they went out from the city by night by way of the gate between the two walls, which was by the king's garden, while the Chaldeans were all around the city; and they went by the way toward the [note]1[/note]Arabah.
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 39[/link].

verse.text: And the army of the Chaldeans pursued after the king, and they overtook Zedekiah in the plains of Jericho; and all his army was scattered from him.
And they seized the [xref]a[/xref]king and brought him up to the king of Babylon at Riblah in the land of Hamath, and he pronounced judgments on him.
Then the king of Babylon slaughtered the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes, and he also slaughtered all the princes of Judah at Riblah.
And he [note]1[/note]put out Zedekiah's eyes and bound him with bronze fetters. And the king of Babylon brought him to Babylon and put him in prison until the day of his [xref]a[/xref]death.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 39[/link].

verse.text: And in the fifth month, on the tenth [i]day[/i] of the month (this was the nineteenth year of King Nebuchadrezzar, the king of Babylon), Nebuzaradan, the captain of the bodyguard, who stood before the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem.
And he [xref]a[/xref]burned the house of Jehovah and the king's house and all the houses of Jerusalem, and every large house he burned with fire.
And all the army of the Chaldeans who were with the captain of the bodyguard broke down all the [xref]a[/xref]walls around Jerusalem.

And the poor of the people and the rest of the people who were left in the city and the deserters who deserted to the king of Babylon and the rest of the multitude, Nebuzaradan the captain of the bodyguard carried away into [xref]a[/xref]exile.
But Nebuzaradan the captain of the bodyguard left some of the [xref]a[/xref]poorest of the land to be vinedressers and field workers.

And the Chaldeans broke in pieces the [xref]a[/xref]bronze [note]1[/note]pillars, which were in the house of Jehovah, and the bases and the bronze sea, which were in the house of Jehovah. And they carried all their bronze to Babylon.
verse.note: For the items of the temple named in [link]vv. 17-23[/link], see notes in [link]1 Kings 6[/link] and [link book="1 Kings"]7[/link].

verse.text: And they took away the [xref]a[/xref]pots and the shovels and the snuffers and the basins and the cups and all the bronze vessels with which they ministered.

And the captain of the bodyguard took away the dishes and the firepans and the basins and the pots and the lampstands and the cups and the bowls, that which was of gold: for [i]its[/i] gold, and that which was of silver, for [i]its[/i] silver.

As for the two pillars, the one sea, and the twelve bronze oxen, which were under the bases, which King Solomon made for the house of Jehovah, the bronze of all these vessels was [xref]a[/xref]beyond weight.
And as for the [xref]a[/xref]pillars, the height of one pillar was eighteen cubits, and it was twelve cubits in circumference, and it was four fingers in thickness; it was hollow.

And a bronze capital was upon it; and the height of each capital was five cubits; and the network and pomegranates were upon the capital all around, all of bronze; and the second pillar and the pomegranates were like these.
And there were ninety-six pomegranates toward the [i]open[/i] air; all the [xref]a[/xref]pomegranates on the network were a hundred all around.
And the captain of the bodyguard took Seraiah the chief priest and Zephaniah the second priest and the three doorkeepers.

And from the city he took one eunuch, who was overseer of the men of war, and seven men from the king's inner circle who were found in the city, and the scribe of the captain of the army, who mustered the people of the land, and sixty men of the people of the land who were found in the midst of the city.
And Nebuzaradan the captain of the bodyguard took them and brought them to the king of Babylon in Riblah.
And the king of Babylon struck them down and put them to death in Riblah, in the land of Hamath; so Judah was carried away into exile out of its land.
These are the people whom Nebuchadrezzar carried into exile: in the [xref]a[/xref]seventh year, three thousand and twenty-three Jews;
In the [xref]a[/xref]eighteenth year of Nebuchadrezzar, eight hundred and thirty-two persons from Jerusalem;

In the [xref]a[/xref]twenty-third year of Nebuchadrezzar, Nebuzaradan the captain of the bodyguard carried from the Jews seven hundred and forty-five persons into exile. There were four thousand six hundred persons in all.

[xref]a[/xref]And in the thirty-seventh year of the exile of Jehoiachin the king of Judah, in the twelfth month, on the twenty-fifth of the month, Evil-merodach the king of Babylon, in the year that he became king, released Jehoiachin the king of Judah and brought him out of prison.
And he spoke with him kindly and set his throne above the thrones of the kings who were with him in Babylon.
And [i]Jehoiachin[/i] changed his prison garments and ate [i]his[/i] food before him continually all the days of his life.
And for his allowance, a continual allowance was given to him by the king of Babylon, a portion for each day, all the days of his life until the day of his death.
